A national survey conducted by Pew Research Center in December 2015 [6] found that only 46% of surveyed adults believed the government was doing very or fairly well in reducing the threat of terrorism. ![The graph visualizes the percentage of Americans who believe the government is doing "Very/Fairly well" or "Not too/Not at all well" in reducing the threat of terrorism from 2001 to 2015.](image4) This represents a 26 percentage point decrease from January of the same year, marking the lowest point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [1].  This negative sentiment towards the government’s efforts to combat terrorism is seen across the political spectrum, with a stark difference between Republicans and Democrats [9]. In January 2015, 63% of Republicans viewed the government's anti-terrorism efforts favorably, but this plummeted to a mere 27% by December [9].  On the other hand, while Democrats also showed a decline, they remained the only group with a majority (64%) still holding a positive view of the government’s efforts [9].

According to a Pew Research Center study conducted from April 29 to May 5, 2020, trust in information about the Coronavirus outbreak varied significantly across different demographics in the United States [7]. The study found that trust in sources like the World Health Organization (WHO) and the European Union (EU) was higher among Americans with higher levels of education [2]. For example, roughly 70% of individuals with postgraduate degrees reported trusting information from the WHO [5]. Conversely, only half of respondents with a high school degree or less indicated trust in information from the WHO [8].  This trend of higher trust in the WHO and EU among more educated Americans is further illustrated in the study's findings [9]. ![The image displays a bar chart showing different levels of confidence or agreement across various demographic groups.](image2)  Additionally, the study revealed a significant partisan divide in trust towards these organizations [11]. ![The image is a chart showing the trust levels among different political groups for the WHO (World Health Organization), EU (European Union), and the Chinese government.](image3) 40% of those aged 65+  had a "great deal" or "fair amount" of trust in information from the WHO, while 86% of postgraduates trusted information from the EU a "great deal" or a "fair amount" [12]. 

12% more people over 65 years old do not trust information from the World Health Organization compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union in regard to the coronavirus outbreak.

A majority of Republicans, specifically 62%, believe that the rise in COVID-19 cases is primarily due to increased testing rather than a surge in new infections [7].  This perspective aligns with their general trust in state and local governments over the federal government in handling the pandemic. ![The image is a bar chart showing the level of trust in government by political affiliation in the U.S.](image2)  Republicans show a strong preference (68%) for state and local governments to take the lead in developing and implementing COVID-19 control policies, compared to only 30% who believe the federal government should bear this responsibility.  ![The image is a bar chart comparing two perspectives on whether more people are getting tested versus there being more new infections. It is segmented by political affiliation:](image8) This partisan divide is evident across various aspects of the pandemic response. 
62% of Rep/Lean Rep people think cases have risen primally because of more testing and 30% of Rep/Lean Rep people think the federal government should be primarily responsible for COVID-19 control policy.

The sample consisted of 449 completed interviews from the landline sampling frame and 1,051 interviews from the cellphone sampling frame [4]. For the full sample, a total of 795 respondents were foreign-born (excluding Puerto Rico) [11]. ![The table provides sample size and margin of error for three different groups](image1)  Therefore, more Latinos were interviewed by cellphone than foreign-born Latinos in the survey. 

The number of Latinos interviewed by cellphone is greater.

Within 90 minutes of the Germanwings Flight 4U 9525 crash on March 24, 2015, both Airbus and Lufthansa utilized their Twitter accounts to acknowledge the incident [1]. Airbus, in particular, saw a significant increase in their Twitter followers following the crash [10].  ![(Airbus twitter account)](image5) Airbus also posted a pop-up notification on their website to acknowledge the incident [9]. ![ Airbus released a statement regarding the crash of Germanwings Flight 4U 9525](image4) The company also released a statement ensuring their full assistance to French authorities in the investigation [4].  Similar to their response to the Costa Concordia and Asiana Airlines incidents, social media platforms became crucial for Airbus in disseminating information and managing their online presence [8]. ![The screenshot shows the Airbus website.](image8) This tragic event highlighted the importance of a robust social media strategy in crisis situations. The share prices of both Lufthansa and Airbus experienced a sharp decline immediately after the news broke; however, they stabilized within approximately two hours [2]. Airbus has 5,436 tweets, 893 accounts followed, 281K followers, and 437 favorites. [5]

There are **4 figures** related to Airbus.

Republican and Republican-leaning voters have remained largely consistent in their desire for the party to take a more conservative stance from 2008 to 2016.  [9] ![The image shows a horizontal bar chart comparing the percentage of "More moderate" and "More conservative" individuals or groups from 2008 to 2016.](image4) Conversely, the share of Democratic voters who prefer a more liberal stance has risen considerably. While a majority of Democrats favored a moderate approach in 2008 [5] and 2012, nearly half now support a more liberal direction. In 2016, 26% of Trump voters believed that he should appoint Democrats to his administration, while 21% believed he should not and 52% said it didn't matter. [7] ![The image is a bar chart representing opinions from November 2016 and November 2008 on whether something "should," "should not," or "doesn't matter." It includes data for all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters for November 2016. For November 2016:

- Among all voters, 55% believe "should," 10% believe "should not," and 33% believe "doesn't matter."
- Among Trump voters, 26% believe "should," 21% believe "should not," and 52% believe "doesn't matter."
- Among Clinton voters, 84% believe "should," 1% believe "should not," and 15% believe "doesn't matter."

No data is provided in the image for November 2008. There are labeled color-coded bars indicating the corresponding percentages.](image8)  In contrast, 52% of Obama voters in 2008 favored appointing Republicans to his cabinet. [10] ![The image is a bar chart that shows the percentage of different groups of voters with regard to whether they believe Barack Obama should appoint Republicans to serve in important positions in his administration. The data is broken down into three groups:

1. All voters:
   - 60% said Obama should appoint Republicans.
   - 4% were unsure or did not answer.
   - 35% said Obama should not appoint Republicans.

2. Obama voters:
   - 52% said Obama should appoint Republicans.
   - 5% were unsure or did not answer.
   - 41% said Obama should not appoint Republicans.

3. McCain voters:
   - 69% said Obama should appoint Republicans.
   - 2% were unsure or did not answer.
   - 27% said Obama should not appoint Republicans.

The chart visually represents this data with horizontal bars of varying lengths corresponding to the percentage values.](image7) This demonstrates that Obama voters were twice as likely to support appointing opposition party members to the cabinet compared to Trump voters. Fewer Trump voters supported appointing Democrats than opposed it, while the opposite was true for Obama voters. Trump voters were much more likely to say that appointing members of the opposite party didn't matter. A greater percentage of Obama voters in 2008 supported appointing opposition members than the total percentage of Trump voters who either supported it or said it didn't matter in 2016. A smaller percentage of Obama voters opposed appointing Republicans than the percentage of Trump voters who either supported appointing Democrats or said it didn't matter.  A greater percentage of McCain voters in 2008 supported having Obama appoint Republicans to his cabinet than the total percentage of Trump voters who either supported or opposed appointing Democrats in 2016.  Only 27% of McCain voters opposed Obama appointing Republicans. [7] This is less than the combined percentage of Trump voters who said that appointing Democrats to the cabinet either didn't matter or shouldn't happen. [7]  These numbers suggest that voters in 2008 were more open to the idea of the president appointing members of the opposing party to their cabinet than voters in 2016. Trump voters were much less likely than Obama voters to support appointing a member of the opposite party, and more likely to be indifferent towards the idea. Voters in 2008 were also more likely to be happy about the results of the election than voters in 2016. [9]  This suggests that the 2016 election led to more polarization and less willingness to compromise than the 2008 election. Obama voters were far more likely to be open to appointing members of the opposing party than Trump voters.
In conclusion, Obama voters in 2008 were substantially more likely to support appointing opposition party members to the cabinet than Trump voters in 2016.

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers:  46% say it is more likely, while 45% say it is not more likely [7]. The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of 50% in September 2014. For much of the past decade, public views on this measure have been closely divided [7]. ![The image is a line graph comparing two perceptions over time (from 2002 to 2015) regarding the encouragement of violence among followers of a religion versus other religions.](image4) However, perceptions about the relationship between Islam and violence have become more politically polarized [6]. The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been [11].  About two-thirds (68%) of Republicans say Islam is more likely to encourage violence, little changed from September 2014 (67%), but the highest share saying this on a question that dates to 2002 [1]. ![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image2) In contrast, the share of Democrats associating Islam with violence has declined 12 percentage points since last year, from 42% to 30%  [1]. The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence is down 14-points since the fall of 2014 [10]. Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have remained relatively stable over time, but there is a growing partisan divide with Republicans becoming more likely and Democrats less likely to believe that Islam encourages violence.

A significant majority of Americans—about three quarters [8]—believe it’s realistic that robots and computers could one day perform many human jobs. This sentiment is echoed in their familiarity with automation's potential impact on employment, with  85% having heard or read about it [2]. ![The image shows a horizontal bar chart about how much people have heard about the concept.](image5)  However, Americans are more likely to express worry (72%) than enthusiasm (33%) about this future [1]. This apprehension is reflected in their anticipation of possible negative outcomes of automation, such as increased inequality and difficulty finding purpose in life. ![The image is a bar graph depicting survey results on the likelihood of various outcomes of automation.](image1) Notably, familiarity with the concept of automation significantly shapes perceptions. Those who have heard a lot about it are more likely to find it extremely realistic and express enthusiasm, compared to those less familiar [4, 6, 12]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing survey responses about a concept related to automation and its perceived realism, enthusiasm, and worry.](image6) Despite the overall worry, Americans acknowledge the potential benefits of automation, such as increased economic efficiency and allowing people to focus on more meaningful pursuits. However, they remain less convinced about these positive outcomes compared to the potential downsides [1].  In conclusion, while Americans generally find the concept of machines performing human jobs realistic, they are more worried than enthusiastic about it, primarily due to concerns about negative societal impacts.

The public is generally in favor of limiting machines to primarily those jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [4]. ![The graph shows that 85% of Americans favor limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image1) 85% of Americans favor this type of policy, with nearly half (47%) saying they favor it strongly [6]. While there is support for limiting the use of machines in the workforce, there is a split when it comes to replacing human jobs entirely. 58% believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, even if machines are better and cheaper, while 41% think businesses are justified in replacing human workers if it means better work at lower costs [1]. ![The pie chart shows 58% support limits on replacing human jobs with machines, even if machines are better and cheaper.](image8)  The public is more supportive of limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines [2].

In conclusion, a majority of the public supports the idea of limiting machines to jobs that are dangerous for humans, but there are mixed views when it comes to replacing human jobs with machines for better efficiency.

Among Latinos, larger shares of both Democrats  $(55\%)$  and independents and other nonpartisans  $(54\%)$  report having experienced racial discrimination than Republicans  $(44\%)$ [7].  Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners  $(73\%)$  say people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem [8]. ![The image is a bar graph comparing perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos.](image1) By contrast, about six-in-ten Republicans and Republican leaners $(62\%)$  say it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it really does not exist [8]. Latino Democrats $(75\%)$  are more likely than Latino Republicans $(36\%)$  or Latino independents and nonpartisans $(56\%)$  to say people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem for the country [2].  Latino Democrats are more likely than Latino Republicans to say that people not seeing racial discrimination when it exists is a bigger problem.

The Pew Research Center found that a lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from a young age is a major reason for the underrepresentation of women, Blacks, and Hispanics in these fields, with 39% of Americans attributing this to the lack of women in STEM and 41% attributing this to the lack of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM [1].  This is further supported by the finding that STEM workers are more likely to cite a lack of encouragement to pursue STEM subjects at a young age as a reason for underrepresentation in STEM (45% vs. 40% of non-STEM workers) [8]. Limited access to quality education is another key factor, with about half of STEM workers believing this to be a major reason for the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM [3]. ![The image is a bar chart that illustrates the major reasons why more women, blacks, and Hispanics are not in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) jobs.](image5)  Furthermore, 42% of Americans agree that limited access to quality education is a significant contributor to this disparity, a view shared by a majority of Black STEM workers (73%) and about half of Hispanics (53%), Asians (52%), and Whites (50%) in STEM [11].  Discrimination also plays a role, with 72% of Black STEM professionals citing discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions as a major reason for underrepresentation, compared to only around a quarter of Whites (27%) and Asians (28%) [4].  The data clearly shows that a combination of systemic barriers, societal perceptions, and biases contribute to the underrepresentation of these groups in STEM. The major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs are lack of encouragement at a young age, lack of access to quality education, and discrimination.

While most Americans give positive ratings for how well the K-12 public schools teach reading, writing and mathematics, public assessments of STEM education for U.S. students in grades K-12  are middling [6].  Only 25% of U.S. adults believe K-12 public schools are the best in the world or above average, 43% say they are average, and 30% think they are below average ![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing the perceptions of U.S. adults regarding the quality of different levels of education in the U.S.: K-12 public schools, undergraduate education, and graduate education. Each education level is divided into three categories reflecting perceptions of quality: "Best in the world/above average," "Average," and "Below average."

- For K-12 public schools, 25% of respondents believe they are "Best in the world/above average," 43% say they are "Average," and 30% think they are "Below average."
- In terms of undergraduate education, 35% of respondents believe it is "Best in the world/above average," 46% consider it "Average," and 17% view it as "Below average."
- For graduate education, 38% of respondents see it as "Best in the world/above average," 43% rate it as "Average," and 17% regard it as "Below average."](image5).  However,  only 13% of those with a STEM postgraduate degree rate K-12 STEM education as above average, and about half (51%) say the U.S. is below average in this regard [11]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the distribution of STEM postgraduate degree holders across different educational levels:

- **K-12 public schools:** 13% dark blue, 36% medium blue, 51% light green.
- **Undergraduate:** 52% dark blue, 35% medium blue, 13% light green.
- **Graduate:** 62% dark blue, 28% medium blue, 9% light green.](image4).  U.S. adults perceive K-12 education more favorably than STEM postgraduate degree holders.

The levels of confidence and likelihood are assessed based on expert evaluation and consensus of the chapter author teams [11]. The author teams determine these levels by thoroughly reviewing the available literature, evaluating the quality and quantity of evidence, and considering the agreement across different studies [11].  ![{This image shows a chart describing different levels of confidence based on the strength and reliability of evidence}](image8) For instance, a "Very High" confidence level suggests strong evidence from multiple consistent sources with established theory and well-documented methods [8]. On the other hand, "Low" confidence implies inconclusive evidence, limited sources, inconsistent findings, and a lack of expert consensus [8]. 

Furthermore, the report uses likelihood language to describe the probability of an impact occurring, ranging from "very unlikely" (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance) to "very likely" (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) [3]. ![{This image visually represents probability terms and their corresponding numerical ranges}](image4)  This quantitative approach helps in understanding the uncertainty associated with projections [2].  All sources used in the report, aiming to provide a comprehensive estimation of climate change-related health impacts in the United States, meet the standards of the Information Quality Act (IQA) [12].  

In conclusion, the levels of confidence and likelihood are determined through a rigorous evaluation of available evidence, expert consensus, and a quantitative assessment of the probability of projected impacts.

A little over 40% of Americans believe that both the Republican and Democratic parties have high ethical standards. [3] However, when examining opinions across different educational backgrounds, a more nuanced picture emerges. ![This image is a bar chart with three categories:

1. **Describes both parties** - Bars in gold color representing the percentage who think both political parties are described by certain attributes.
2. **Describes one party, not the other** - Bars in light gold color representing the percentage who think one party is described by certain attributes, not the other.
3. **Describes neither party** - Bars in gray color representing the percentage who think neither party is described by certain attributes.

The data is broken down by groups including:
- Total
- Education levels: College grad+, Some college, HS or less
- Political affiliation: Republican, Democrat, Independent, Lean Republican, Lean Democrat

Percentages are provided for each group, showing how they perceive the political parties.](image4) Notably, those with at least a college degree are more likely than those with some college education or a high school diploma or less to believe that neither party upholds high ethical standards (31% vs 24% and 22% respectively). [10] This trend is also visible when looking at perceptions of extremism.  While 48% of Americans view the Republican Party as too extreme compared to 42% for the Democratic Party, these figures fluctuate depending on political affiliation.  [8, 12] Unsurprisingly, a significant majority of Republicans and those who lean Republican believe their own party is not too extreme, while the opposite is true for Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals.  [11]  ![The image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties among U.S. adults. It includes three statements:

1. "Has good policy ideas": Both parties are rated equally at 50%.
2. "Has high ethical standards": The Democratic Party is rated slightly higher at 42% compared to the Republican Party at 41%.
3. "Is too extreme": The Republican Party is rated higher at 48%, with the Democratic Party at 42%.

The source is a survey conducted from April 25 to May 1, 2018.](image1) Interestingly, independents are considerably more likely than individuals affiliated with either party to believe that neither party has high ethical standards (34% vs 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats). [5]  This suggests that those who do not identify with either major party may hold a more critical view of both parties' ethical practices. Perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism differ significantly across educational levels and political affiliations, with those who are more educated and politically independent often holding more critical views of both major parties.

Public perception reveals a notable disparity between the Republican and Democratic parties regarding ethical standards and extremism.  While a close  $42\%$ of Americans believe the Democratic Party upholds high ethical standards, the Republican Party trails slightly behind at  $41\%$ [1]. This difference widens when considering perceptions of extremism, with  $48\%$  viewing the Republican Party as "too extreme," compared to  $42\%$  for the Democratic Party [7]. ![This bar chart compares public perception of the Republican and Democratic parties across three statements: possessing good policy ideas, upholding high ethical standards, and being "too extreme".](image1) Notably, education plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions.  Among individuals with at least a college degree, a mere  $17\%$  believe that both parties maintain high ethical standards, while a more substantial  $31\%$  assert that neither party meets this criterion [3]. This suggests a greater degree of skepticism towards both parties' ethical conduct among highly educated individuals.  ![This bar chart displays the percentage of individuals, categorized by education level and political affiliation, who believe that high ethical standards describe both parties, one party but not the other, or neither party.](image4) Furthermore, political affiliation heavily influences these views. Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to perceive neither party as possessing high ethical standards, with $34\%$  of independents, including an equal proportion of Republican and Democratic leaners, sharing this sentiment [5].  Conversely, only a small fraction of Republicans ($19\%$) and Democrats ($18\%$) hold this view, underscoring the impact of party loyalty on perceptions of ethics [5]. ![This bar chart presents data on the percentage of individuals within each political affiliation group, further categorized by leaning, who believe that neither the Republican nor the Democratic party upholds high ethical standards.](image2)  In conclusion, while perceptions of ethical standards are relatively similar for both parties, a greater proportion of Americans view the Republican Party as "too extreme." These perceptions are significantly influenced by education and political affiliation, with highly educated individuals and independents demonstrating more critical stances toward both parties.

Americans' views on the ethical standards of the Republican and Democratic parties are quite similar, with 41% stating the GOP has high ethical standards and 42% saying the same about the Democratic Party [1].  However, a significant education gap emerges when examining these perceptions.  Among those with at least a college degree, 31% believe that “high ethical standards” does not describe either the GOP or the Democratic Party, while 43% believe it describes one party but not the other [10]. This contrasts with individuals holding a high school degree or less, where only 20% feel neither party meets this ethical standard [12]. ![The image is a bar chart with three categories: **Describes both parties**, **Describes one party, not the other**, **Describes neither party**](image5) Political affiliation also plays a crucial role in shaping these opinions. While a mere 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats believe neither party possesses high ethical standards, this number rises significantly to 34% among independents [9]. Interestingly, this trend remains consistent among independent voters regardless of whether they lean towards the Republican or Democratic party, with 33% in each subgroup expressing this sentiment [9]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions among different political groups.](image2)  When analyzing political party preference through an educational lens, a clear pattern emerges: higher education levels correlate with a stronger preference for the Democratic party. Individuals with postgraduate degrees favor Democratic candidates over Republican candidates by a substantial margin of 62% to 30% [8]. This trend continues, albeit less pronounced, among those with four-year college degrees, where Democrats hold a 53% to 40% advantage [8]. In conclusion, perceptions of ethical standards are influenced by education level, with higher education correlating with a more critical view of both parties. Similarly, political affiliation significantly shapes these perceptions, with independents demonstrating more skepticism towards both parties' ethical standards. Additionally, higher education levels show a strong association with a preference for the Democratic party.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy saw an increase from 46% in January 2018 to 53% in May 2018, as illustrated in the line graph depicting changes in public confidence over time. ![The image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas](image5) This suggests a mixed but slightly more positive view of his economic management.  However, there's a stark contrast when considering perceptions of his ethical standards. [12] Only 38% of Republicans view the ethical standards of Trump and his administration favorably, while a significantly higher 86% of Democrats hold negative views. [3, 9] This partisan divide is further emphasized when looking at how different groups rate the ethical standards of the Trump administration.  ![The image is a bar chart that appears to show ratings divided into four categories: Poor, Not good, Good, and Excellent.](image8) While 75% of Republicans give high marks, a mere 12% of Democrats share this sentiment, indicating a deep ideological chasm in the assessment of ethical conduct. [9] In conclusion, while views on Trump's economic policies show some positive movement, his ethical standards elicit sharply contrasting opinions, largely divided along partisan lines.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has ticked up since January  ($46\%$ then, $53\%$ now) [10].  Similarly,  confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis has also risen from $35\%$ in January to $43\%$ today [12]. ![This image shows a line graph of Trump's approval rating in handling international crises and economic policy from April 2017 to May 2018.](image3) This upward trend is further supported by data revealing that $53\%$ of respondents express at least some confidence in Trump's economic decision-making [7]. However, despite these improvements, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic and international crises remains mixed [11]. ![This image is a bar chart depicting public perception of Trump's effectiveness in various areas, including negotiating trade agreements, economic policy, military force, federal court appointments, managing the executive branch, immigration policy, handling international crises, and working with Congress.](image1) This suggests that while there have been improvements, a significant portion of the population still holds reservations.

These overall trends, however, mask a stark partisan divide. While Republican confidence in Trump's handling of international crises has surged to $84\%$  [9], only $54\%$ of the general public shares this sentiment [6].  This discrepancy highlights the deeply ingrained partisan perspectives shaping public opinion. ![This image is a bar chart showing opinions about Trump from Republicans and Democrats from August 2017 to May 2018. ](image8) In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has increased, this is largely driven by Republicans, and overall public opinion remains mixed.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has ticked up since January 2018, from 46% to 53% [9]. ![The image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas](image2) This is in line with a general increase in public confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis, which is up to 43% from a low of 35% in January [4]. However, this is still lower than the 48% confidence level recorded in April 2017 [4]. These trends are interesting to note in light of the stark contrast between Republican and Democrat sentiment towards Trump’s conduct. While 80% of Republicans agree with Trump on many or all issues [10], 85% of Democrats disapprove of his conduct [8].  ![This image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017.](image1)  Furthermore, only 5% of Democrats like his behavior, compared to 38% of Republicans who feel the same way [2] [8]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing people's opinions, categorized by political affiliation.](image5) In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's handling of the economy and international crises has increased,  a large divide persists between Republican and Democrat opinions of his overall conduct.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy [12] has ticked up since January (53% now, 46% then) [12]. ![The image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas](image8) Confidence in Trump to handle an international  crisis [11], up from  35%  in  January [11]; last April,  48%  had at least some confidence in  Trump’s ability to handle an  international crisis [11]. Public confidence in Trump to handle international crisis and economy ticks up [10]. Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis is lower than his ability to make good decisions about economic policy, but both have increased since the beginning of his presidency.

[8] The public’s evaluation of Trump's job performance has remained relatively consistent. However, there are significant differences in opinions among Republicans and Democrats. [3] Democrats heavily criticize Trump's conduct, with 85% disapproving of how he conducts himself in office. This sentiment has remained consistent since August [4]. In contrast, only 38% of Republicans approve of his conduct, while 45% have mixed feelings [3]. ![This image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017.](image2) This partisan divide is also evident in the perception of ethical standards within the Trump administration. [1] While 40% of Americans view the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as good or excellent, 58% find them not good or poor. This partisan gap is further highlighted by the fact that 80% of Republicans agree with Trump on many or all issues, marking an 11 percentage point increase since August [12]. Conversely, only 12% of Democrats share this sentiment. ![This image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017.](image2) This difference in opinion is starkly reflected in the assessment of ethical standards within the Trump administration. ![The image is a bar chart that appears to show ratings divided into four categories: Poor, Not good, Good, and Excellent. The data is segmented into three groups: Total, Rep/Lean Rep, and Dem/Lean Dem.](image3) In conclusion, the opinions of Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have remained largely unchanged, with Democrats expressing strong disapproval and Republicans generally more supportive.

The Trump administration receives low marks for its ethical standards, with only 39% of the public rating them as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor [7].  This aligns with the public's overall evaluation of Trump's job performance, which remains largely unchanged and comparable to ratings at the beginning of his presidency [3]. ![The image is a bar chart showing approval ratings of U.S. presidents over various years.](image7) These current ratings for the Trump administration's ethical standards are notably lower than those of previous administrations since 1983 [11].  Despite this, there's a significant split in opinion along party lines. A considerable majority of Republicans (75%) view the ethical standards of key administration members favorably, while 86% of Democrats disagree, with 61% even rating them as poor [12].  This partisan divide is also evident in the overall approval of Trump, with a significant gap between Republicans and Democrats. ![This image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017.](image6) This suggests that the public's perception of Trump's job performance is closely tied to their views on his administration's ethical standards, particularly influenced by their political affiliations. The public's low approval of the Trump administration's ethical standards aligns with the low public approval of Trump's overall job performance.

[9] Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to believe that neither party upholds "high ethical standards," with about a third of independents (34%) holding this view compared to only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%). This trend is further illustrated when considering educational attainment. [4] For instance, only 20% of those with a high school degree or less think neither party has high ethical standards, whereas this figure rises to 26% for those with some college experience.  ![This image is a bar graph showing how closely different demographic groups follow an unspecified subject, with categories such as race, age, and political affiliation.](image2) This suggests a correlation between higher education levels and a more critical view of both parties' ethical standards. While [2] 52% of voters were happy about Obama's win in 2012, only half were happy about Trump’s victory in 2016, with a near equal percentage (48%) expressing unhappiness [6]. This suggests a more divided reaction to Trump's election compared to previous elections. Notably, [7] a significantly lower percentage of Clinton voters (15%) were satisfied with Trump's win in 2016 compared to McCain supporters (39%) who were satisfied with Obama's win in 2008 ![Comparing the percentage of voters' satisfaction for winning and losing candidates from the U.S. elections in 2016 and 2008.](image4). 

Furthermore, after Trump's victory, the most common emotion among voters was surprise, with [3] 73% expressing this sentiment, including a staggering 87% of Clinton voters ![This image is a horizontal bar chart comparing the levels of surprise among different voter groups.](image8). The 2016 election also saw a significant increase in negative emotions: [9] 53% of voters felt uneasy, 41% felt sad, and 41% felt scared ![The image is a bar chart depicting different emotions and their corresponding values.](image2).  

These reactions, combined with [4] negative assessments of the campaign itself, suggest that the 2016 election was a particularly divisive and emotionally charged event. Voter reactions in 2016 differed significantly from previous elections, marked by heightened negativity, surprise, and a sense of unease following Trump's victory.

An overwhelming majority of Trump voters, [6], felt hopeful ([96\%](image5))  and proud ([74\%](image5)) about his election.  In contrast, Clinton voters overwhelmingly felt negative emotions. For example, [7],  [90\%] of Clinton voters felt uneasy, with sadness and fear being similarly widespread reactions ([77\%](image5) and [76\%](image5), respectively).  This stark contrast in emotional response extends to expectations of Trump's first term. While [6] an overwhelming 97% of Trump voters expected a successful first term, only [9] 15% of Clinton voters shared that optimism.  ![The image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of voters' satisfaction for winning and losing candidates from the U.S. elections in 2016 and 2008.](image1) This difference mirrors the sentiment observed when comparing voter satisfaction with the 2008 election, where 39% of McCain voters expected Obama to have a successful first term. Trump voters overwhelmingly felt hopeful and proud, while Clinton voters predominantly felt uneasy, sad, and scared, a difference reflected in their expectations of Trump’s first term.

Following the 2016 election, voters' opinions on the potential success of Trump's first term were sharply divided along partisan lines. [9] An overwhelming 97% of Trump voters expected him to have a successful first term, mirroring the 92% of Obama voters who felt similarly in 2008. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of voters' satisfaction for winning and losing candidates from the U.S. elections in 2016 and 2008.](image8) Conversely, Clinton voters held a much more pessimistic outlook, with just 15% believing Trump's first term would be successful.  [10] This stark contrast extended beyond general expectations to a more personal level, as nearly four-in-ten (39%) Clinton voters admitted they couldn't envision giving Trump a chance due to his perceived character.  [1] This sentiment is palpable in the emotional responses of Clinton voters, with a significant majority reporting feelings of unease (90%), sadness (77%), fear (76%), and anger (62%). ![The image is a bar chart comparing the emotional reactions of Trump voters and Clinton voters to an unspecified event or context.](image1)  Despite these reservations, a slim majority of Clinton voters (58%) remained open to giving Trump a chance to prove himself as president. [11] However, the data highlights a clear and substantial divide in the post-election sentiments of Trump and Clinton voters, particularly regarding the anticipated success of Trump's presidency and their willingness to offer him a chance. Clinton voters were far less optimistic about Trump's chances of a successful first term and significantly less willing to give him a chance than Trump voters.

![This image is a table showing the percentage of Trump voters and Clinton voters who believe certain issues should be the main priority of the president-elect.](image5)  For example, while  $29\%$ of Trump voters see health care as a main priority for Trump, only $12\%$ of Clinton voters agree [9]. This difference likely reflects that, among those who mentioned specific actions they wanted taken regarding healthcare, Trump voters were more likely to mention repealing the Affordable Care Act, while Clinton voters were more likely to mention maintaining or fixing it [10]. Clinton voters were more likely than Trump voters to prioritize unifying the country ($12\%$ vs. $5\%$) [5].  This difference in priorities suggests that Trump and Clinton voters have different views on his leadership. Clinton voters, many of whom are concerned about the divisions stoked during Trump's campaign [4], are looking for Trump to prioritize healing the country. Trump voters, on the other hand, seem more focused on policy issues like health care. ![This image is a bar graph displaying survey results on how much people care about certain issues.](image2) However, it is worth noting that Clinton voters are more likely to be unsure about Trump's goals for the country with $84\%$ saying they do not have a good idea of his vision [8]. 

Trump and Clinton voters have different priorities for Trump's presidency, with Clinton voters prioritizing unifying the country and Trump voters focusing on issues like healthcare, suggesting  differences in how they view his leadership.

Clinton voters are far less confident about Trump's ability to handle foreign policy, with 63% expressing no confidence at all in his approach [9]. ![The chart compares levels of concern among Trump and Clinton voters regarding five key issues: Economy, Threat of terrorism, Health care, Illegal immigration, and Foreign policy.](image7) This sentiment starkly contrasts with Trump voters, the majority of whom express at least a fair amount of confidence in his foreign policy [1].  This partisan divide also extends to their expectations for race relations following the election. Clinton voters overwhelmingly believe that race relations will worsen under Trump's presidency, with 84% anticipating a negative impact [11]. This view sharply contrasts with Trump voters, half of whom believe race relations will improve, and another 38% who believe his election won't significantly impact race relations [7]. ![The image presents a bar chart illustrating differing opinions on whether specific political occurrences resulted in improvement, stagnation, or deterioration, with a focus on the 2016 and 2008 elections and reactions from Trump and Clinton voters.](image6)  Clinton voters are significantly less confident in Trump's handling of foreign policy and believe his election will worsen race relations compared to Trump voters.

By contrast,   $46\%$   of voters say race  relations will get worse after Trump’s election, and  $_{26\%}$   say his election will make no difference. In contrast, only 25% of voters believe Trump's election will improve race relations. [8] A much larger proportion, 46%, foresee a worsening of race relations. Regarding the impact of enthusiastic supporters on a president's effectiveness, a Pew Research Center survey reveals a general consensus that it does not hinder their ability to get things done. 
![{The chart depicts the percentage of Trump, Clinton, and all voters who agree or disagree with the statement "When a president has supporters who are highly enthusiastic about him, less gets done"}](image1)
73% of all voters disagreed with the notion that passionate supporters impede a president's ability to govern effectively. Interestingly, Trump voters were less likely to disagree with the statement than Clinton voters, suggesting a potential difference in perception of how political enthusiasm translates into tangible outcomes.

Voters' expectations for race relations after the 2016 election are significantly more negative than their expectations for partisan relations, and there is a general belief that having enthusiastic supporters does not hinder a president's ability to govern.

Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction for their party. ![The chart shows a stable preference for "More conservative" over time, ranging from 57% to 60%.](image1)  This preference has remained largely unchanged in recent years, with 60% supporting a conservative stance in 2016 [9].  On the other hand, Democratic voters have shown a notable shift towards a more liberal stance in recent years. While a third of Democratic voters favored a more liberal direction following Obama’s victories in 2008 and 2012, this number rose to 38% in 2014 and reached 49% in 2016 [10]. This indicates a growing desire for a more progressive agenda within the Democratic base. ![The chart illustrates a growing trend towards "More liberal" from 2008 to 2016, particularly noticeable after 2012.](image2)  These shifting political orientations align with the reactions to the 2016 election results. Trump voters overwhelmingly expressed happiness (94%) with the Republican Party retaining congressional control [2]. Conversely, the majority of Clinton supporters (87%) were unhappy with the outcome ![The chart highlights the stark contrast in happiness levels between Trump voters (94%) and Clinton voters (10%).](image3),  indicating a strong correlation between political leaning and election satisfaction.  In conclusion, while Republican voters have consistently favored a conservative direction, Democratic voters have shifted towards a more liberal stance, a trend reflected in their reactions to the 2016 election results.

In 2008, there was a greater emphasis on bipartisan cooperation.  A significant majority of Obama's voters (78%) believed that Democratic leaders should prioritize working with Republicans [6].  This sentiment was shared by McCain's voters, with 76% advocating for cooperation [6].  This suggests a broader consensus on the importance of finding common ground. In contrast, the 2016 election revealed a stark partisan divide.  A mere 32% of Democratic voters felt that their leaders should work with Trump, even if it meant compromising on key issues [12]. Conversely, a larger proportion (65%) favored taking a firm stance against Trump's policies [12]. This shift in attitude is likely attributed to the highly polarized political climate and negative perceptions of the 2016 election.  ![The image displays a survey result showing percentages of Clinton voters with their views on giving Trump a chance. The left side indicates 39% "can't see themselves giving Trump a chance because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be." Voters in 2016 were less inclined to support the appointment of opposition party members to key positions, reflecting a more partisan approach to governance. Only 26% of Trump voters supported the appointment of Democrats [3]. In conclusion, voter expectations and sentiments towards political leaders working with newly elected presidents were significantly different between 2008 and 2016, shifting from an emphasis on bipartisan cooperation to a more partisan approach, likely due to increased political polarization and negative perceptions of the electoral process.

Americans’ ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks. [2]  For the first time, more now say the  government is doing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism  (52%)  than  say the government is doing either very or fairly well (46%). [2] Positive ratings have fallen 26 points  since January (when  72%   said very/fairly well). [2] Compared to early 2015, assessments of  government efforts to combat terrorism are  more negative across the political spectrum. [3] Democrats are now the only partisan group in  which a majority (64%) say the government is  doing at least fairly well (down from  85%  in  January). [3] Independents’ positive ratings have  dropped 25 points, from  69%  to 44%. [3] And just  27%  of Republicans now say the government is  doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist  threat, down from 63% at the beginning of the  year. [3] ![The image is a line graph showing data trends over time from 2004 to 2015 for three political affiliations: Republican, Democrat, and Independent.](image2) Older and less educated Americans are somewhat more likely than younger and more highly  educated Americans to give the government low marks for the job it is doing reducing the threat of  terrorism. [4] Among those 50 and older, a majority (57%) say  the government is not doing well reducing the  terrorist threat (42% say that it is). [6] In contrast,  46%  of younger adults (those 18-29 years old)  give the government’s performance a negative  rating, while 53% say it is doing very or fairly  well. [6] Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum since 2001, with older Americans and Republicans expressing greater disapproval compared to younger adults and Democrats.

[11] suggests that older and less educated Americans tend to hold more negative views of the government's counterterrorism efforts. This age-related discrepancy is evident in [4], where 57% of those aged 50 and above disapprove of the government's performance, contrasting with 46% of younger adults (18-29 years old).  ![The table shows opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image1) Notably, younger generations express heightened concern regarding the restriction of civil liberties for national security, as 43% of those aged 18-29 believe the government has gone too far in this regard. This contrasts with older demographics where concern leans more towards security over civil liberties [9].  ![The image is a line graph comparing two perspectives over a period from 2004 to 2015.](image6) shows a notable shift in public opinion since 2004.  While initially, a larger percentage of the population felt the country hadn't gone far enough in its security measures, by 2015, the majority believed the government had gone too far in restricting civil liberties. This shift suggests a growing awareness and concern over the balance between security and freedom, particularly in light of events like the Edward Snowden leaks [8].  Overall, younger generations and those with higher education levels tend to be more critical of the government's approach to terrorism, showing greater concern for the potential infringement on civil liberties. This generational divide highlights the evolving perspectives on security and freedom in a post-9/11 world.  Older and less educated Americans are more likely to give the government low marks for its efforts in reducing the terrorist threat.

Older Americans are more likely to perceive the government's performance in reducing the terrorist threat negatively compared to their younger counterparts. Specifically, [6] indicates that 57% of those aged 50 and older believe the government is not doing well in this area, contrasting with 46% of younger adults (18-29 years old) holding the same view. ![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image5) This difference in perception aligns with the age groups' contrasting stances on anti-terror policies. While 71% of individuals aged 65 and older believe these policies do not go far enough to protect the country, only 44% of those aged 18-29 share this sentiment. This suggests a generational divide, with older adults potentially prioritizing security over civil liberties more strongly than their younger counterparts. In conclusion, older age groups are more likely to view the government's counterterrorism efforts negatively and favor stricter security measures compared to younger age groups.

Public concern over government anti-terrorism policies leaning too far in restricting civil liberties has decreased since 2013. [7] ![This graph shows the percentage of people who believe that the government has either not gone far enough or has gone too far in restricting civil liberties in the name of safety from 2004 to 2015.](image6) This shift is particularly noticeable among Republicans, with 71% now expressing greater concern that policies aren't comprehensive enough in protecting the country. This concern is up 33 points from July 2013. [5]  However, there's a generational divide in how these concerns are perceived.  ![This table presents data on public opinions regarding the balance between civil liberties and national security across different age demographics.](image4) While a majority of those aged 30 and above prioritize security over civil liberties, adults under 30 are almost evenly split on whether the government is too restrictive or not doing enough to protect the country (43% and 44% respectively). [8] Interestingly, despite these concerns about the balance between security and freedom, approval ratings for government efforts in reducing terrorism threats have declined. [3]  ![This table illustrates how different demographics perceive the performance or effectiveness of something, breaking down the results by age, education level, political affiliation, and ideology.](image1) This suggests a complex dynamic where even as certain demographics advocate for stronger security measures, they remain dissatisfied with the perceived effectiveness of the government's actions.  When comparing across political lines, Republicans demonstrate a considerably higher level of concern regarding potential threats, particularly from ISIS (93%), compared to Democrats (79%) and Independents (79%). [2] ![This bar chart presents data on the percentage of Republicans, Democrats, and Independents who perceive various global issues as major threats to the United States.](image2)  This partisan gap highlights the differing perceptions of security threats and the role of government intervention in addressing them. In conclusion, while concern over government overreach in anti-terrorism measures has decreased since 2013, a generational divide exists, and Republicans are more likely to favor stronger security measures compared to Democrats.

Public assessments of the ongoing U.S. military campaign against ISIS have remained largely consistent, with a majority expressing negative views on its current effectiveness [7].  ![Public perception of the effectiveness of the US military campaign against ISIS over time](image1)  This trend has persisted throughout the past year, indicating a degree of skepticism about the campaign's immediate impact. However, there is a notable increase in optimism regarding the long-term success of the campaign [9]. Public opinion has shifted towards a more favorable outlook, with a growing number of Americans believing that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately achieve their objectives. This positive trend is evident in the rising percentage of individuals who believe in the likelihood of success against ISIS. ![Public perception of the likelihood of success of the US military campaign against ISIS, comparing July 2015 and December 2015](image6) Despite this overall positive trajectory, significant partisan divides persist in how the campaign is perceived, particularly concerning its potential for success [2]. While a majority of Republicans, Democrats, and independents express confidence in the eventual success of the campaign, there are clear differences in the levels of support across these groups. ![Public opinion on whether the US military will go far enough to stop militants, divided by political affiliation](image2) Republicans are less likely than Democrats and independents to view the campaign as currently successful, reflecting a greater sense of skepticism within this group.  In conclusion, while public opinion on the immediate effectiveness of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS remains negative, there is growing optimism about its long-term success, though partisan divisions persist.

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers:  $46\%$   say it is more likely, while  $45\%$   say it is not more likely [6].  The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been. Fully  $68\%$   of Republicans say Islam  encourages violence more than other religions,  a historical high but little changed since last  fall [12].  ![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents. The red line represents Republicans, showing an increase from 33% in 2002 to 68% in 2015, with fluctuations in between. The blue line represents Democrats, showing a slight decrease from 22% in 2002 to 30% in 2015, with various ups and downs. These differing perceptions on Islam's relation to violence likely influence opinions on the government's handling of terrorism.  Compared to early 2015, assessments of  government efforts to combat terrorism are  more negative across the political spectrum [5]. Republicans, who are more likely to view Islam as encouraging violence, might be more critical of government efforts to combat terrorism. Democrats are now the only partisan group in  which a majority   $(64\%)$   say the government is  doing at least fairly well [5].  This could suggest that Democrats, who are less likely to associate Islam with violence, might be more supportive of or understanding towards the government's approach to terrorism. Republicans are significantly more likely to view increased scrutiny of Muslims favorably: a majority $(57\%)$ of Conservative Republicans support this, compared to much lower numbers among moderate and liberal Republicans and Democrats [4]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the opinions of different political groups on whether individuals should be subject to additional scrutiny solely because of their religion. The data reflects how different political affiliations view religious scrutiny.](image4)  This difference highlights the connection between perceptions of Islam and attitudes towards security measures, illustrating how political affiliation influences views on both issues. Perceptions of Islam's encouragement of violence vary greatly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans holding significantly more negative views, and these perceptions likely influence their opinions on government handling of terrorism and security measures.

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers: 46% say it is more likely, while 45% say it is not more likely [6]. The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of 50% in September 2014 [6].  For much of the past decade, public views on this measure have been closely divided [6]. ![The image is a line graph comparing two perceptions over time (from 2002 to 2015) regarding the encouragement of violence among followers of a religion versus other religions.](image7) However, this closeness in overall public opinion masks a stark and growing partisan divide [1]. The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been [7]. Fully 68% of Republicans say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a historical high but little changed since last fall [7].  By contrast, just 30% of Democrats say Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, down from 42% in September 2014, but on par with Democratic opinion at other points in recent years [7]. ![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image1) This partisan divide on the perceived link between Islam and violence is reflected in public opinion on the two parties' ability to deal with terrorism. The survey finds that, as has been the case since 2002, the Republican Party has a sizable advantage over the Democrats on terrorism: 46% of the public says the Republican Party can do better in dealing with the terrorist threat at home, compared with 34% who favor the Democrats [8]. ![The image is a chart comparing which political party—Democratic or Republican—people believe could do a better job on various issues.](image5) In conclusion, while overall public opinion on Islam's connection to violence is relatively split, there's a significant and growing partisan divide, aligning with public perception of each party's ability to handle terrorism.

![The image is a bar chart showing the opinions of different political groups on whether individuals should be subject to additional scrutiny solely because of their religion. The groups are divided into "Not be subject to additional scrutiny solely because of religion" and "Be subject to more scrutiny than people in other religious groups." Here's the breakdown:

The data reflects how different political affiliations view religious scrutiny.](image5)  Republicans are roughly evenly divided on whether U.S. Muslims should be subject to greater scrutiny because of their religion [9]. However, there's a clear divide within the party,  conservative Republicans are the only major ideological, demographic or religious group in which  a majority (57%) says Muslims in this country should be subject to greater scrutiny [3].  In contrast, clear majorities of independents (62%) and  Democrats (76%) believe Muslims should not be subject to greater scrutiny because of their  religion [9]. This partisan divide is further illustrated by the fact that Democrats are now the only partisan group in which a majority (64%) say the government is doing at least fairly well combating terrorism [8].  ![The table displays survey results regarding the importance of various issues to different political affiliations: Republicans (Rep), Democrats (Dem), and Independents (Ind). The issues include Defense/National Security, Immigration, Terrorism, ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria, Economy (general), Dissatisfaction with government/Obama, Gun control/Too many guns/Mass shootings, Unemployment, and Political gridlock/Division. 

Each column shows the percentage of respondents from each group that prioritize that issue. Non-whites are more likely than whites to reject the idea of scrutiny of Muslims based on religion [4], and young people are less likely to say Muslims  should receive greater scrutiny because of their faith [2]. This suggests that perceptions of terrorism and its relationship to religious scrutiny are influenced by both political affiliation and demographic factors.  Perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims differ across political and demographic groups, with Republicans and older generations being more likely to support it, and these perceptions are closely tied to the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue.

Americans' ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks. For the first time, more now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) than say the government is doing either very or fairly well (46%). [4]  This represents a significant drop since January when 72% of Americans viewed the government's efforts positively. [4] This downward trend in positive ratings is consistent across the political spectrum, with Democrats, Independents, and Republicans all showing decreased confidence in the government's ability to combat terrorism since early 2015. [12] Notably, older and less educated Americans are more likely to view the government's counterterrorism efforts negatively compared to their younger and more educated counterparts. [1, 9] For instance, a majority (57%) of those aged 50 and older believe the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat. [11] 

![This table appears to show survey results about how different demographic groups perceive how well something is performing or being done.](image3)

Public concern about terrorism has also risen. Nearly three-in-ten (29%) Americans cite terrorism (18%), national security (8%) or ISIS (7%) as the most important problem facing the country today. [10] This represents a substantial increase from the previous year when only 4% of the public considered these issues to be of paramount importance. [10] This heightened concern about terrorism is reflected in the finding that a larger proportion of Americans (56%) now believe that the government's anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough to protect the country, compared to those who think these policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties (28%). [8] 

![The image is a line graph comparing two perspectives over a period from 2004 to 2015.](image7)

The perception of terrorism and the government's efforts to combat it have shifted over time, with declining public confidence in the government's approach and a significant increase in the perceived threat of terrorism, particularly among older and less educated demographics.

Republicans are more likely to cite terrorism as the most important problem facing the nation [9].  In fact, four times as many Republicans than Democrats mention terrorism, defense issues, and national security as the most important problems [9].  ![This table displays survey results regarding the importance of various issues to different political affiliations: Republicans (Rep), Democrats (Dem), and Independents (Ind).](image7) This is likely influenced by the increasing concern about global terrorism, especially the rise of ISIS [4]. Republicans are also more likely to believe that the government's anti-terrorism policies are not doing enough to protect the country [3]. Democrats, on the other hand, are more likely to prioritize economic issues [8]. Notably, Democrats are more likely to mention partisan gridlock as a major problem facing the country compared to Republicans [8].  This partisan divide highlights the different priorities and perceptions of major national issues between the two parties. Republicans tend to prioritize issues related to national security and terrorism, potentially driven by a sense of threat, while Democrats tend to focus on domestic issues such as the economy and political gridlock.  In conclusion, Republicans prioritize terrorism as a major issue while Democrats focus more on economic problems.

[6] Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats or Independents to view terrorism, defense issues, and national security as the most important problem facing the nation. This difference in priorities is reflected in their views on the government's efforts to address the terrorist threat.  ![The table displays survey results regarding the importance of various issues to different political affiliations: Republicans (Rep), Democrats (Dem), and Independents (Ind). The issues include Defense/National Security, Immigration, Terrorism, ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria, Economy (general), Dissatisfaction with government/Obama, Gun control/Too many guns/Mass shootings, Unemployment, and Political gridlock/Division.](image7)  [5] While a majority of Democrats still approve of the government's handling of terrorism, their approval rating has fallen significantly since the start of the year. Republicans, on the other hand, have become much more critical, with only a small percentage now approving of the government's efforts. This partisan gap is likely influenced by the differing levels of concern about terrorism, with Republicans being more likely to see it as a major threat. [7] Conservative Republicans, in particular, have become highly critical of the government's approach to terrorism. In conclusion, Republicans consider terrorism a more important issue than Democrats, and consequently, they are more critical of the government's efforts to address it.

Independents are more divided on government regulation of business. [8] ![The image is a bar chart divided into two sections that represent public opinion on government size and regulation as expressed by different political affiliations.](image3) While a majority of Democrats believe government regulation is necessary, and a majority of Republicans believe it does more harm than good, independents are split almost evenly. [8, 3]  ![The image is a chart from the Pew Research Center that illustrates public opinion on whether the current system of government unfairly favors powerful interests or is generally fair to most Americans. It presents data from a survey of U.S. adults conducted between September 18-24, 2018.](image2)  When it comes to the fairness of the U.S. economic system, independents' views are closer to those of Democrats than Republicans. A majority of both Democrats and independents believe that the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests. [3] Republican views are much more divided on this issue. [12] Independents' views on government regulation are more aligned with Democrats', while their opinions on economic fairness are closer to Democrats' than Republicans'.

Over the past two decades, Republicans and Democrats have increasingly viewed the opposing party more negatively, and this trend is also evident among independents who lean toward a party. [9] ![The image is a line graph depicting the percentage of various political affiliations with an unfavorable view of the Republican and Democratic parties over time, from 1994 to 2018.](image8)  While a majority of independents (81%) lean towards one of the two major parties, [6] there are notable differences in how independents view the parties. Independents who do not lean toward a party are the most likely to have unfavorable opinions of both parties (37%). [4, 11] In contrast, independents who lean towards a party tend to align with the views of their preferred party, holding unfavorable views of the opposing party at levels similar to party identifiers. [1, 2]  However, the share of independents who view both parties negatively has declined in recent years. [8] ![The image is a data visualization that shows the percentage of people who have favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties, broken down by different political affiliations.](image5) In 2015, over a third of independents (36%) viewed both parties unfavorably. [8] Despite this decline, there's a clear trend of increasing polarization, with partisan groups, including independent leaners, expressing increasingly negative views towards the opposing party.  Unfavorable views towards both major U.S. political parties have declined among independents in recent years, although independents without a party lean are most likely to view both parties unfavorably.

Over the past two decades, Republicans and Democrats have increasingly viewed the opposing party more negatively [7]. This trend of growing polarization is evident in the rising percentage of both Democrats and Republicans expressing unfavorable opinions of the other major party since 1994 ![The image is a line graph depicting the percentage of various political affiliations with an unfavorable view of the Republican and Democratic parties over time, from 1994 to 2018.](image6). Currently, 87% of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, while 88% of Democrats view the Republican Party unfavorably  [2]. This negativity towards the opposing party is also reflected among those who lean towards a specific party [7].  However, independents show a different pattern: while a greater share of independents view both parties unfavorably compared to those who identify with a party [8], this share has actually decreased in recent years.  In fact,  the percentage of independents holding unfavorable opinions of both parties peaked in 2015 at 36% and has since fallen to 28% [9]. ![The image is a data visualization that shows the percentage of people who have favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties, broken down by different political affiliations.](image7). Among independents, 15% have a favorable view of both parties, 23% favor Republicans while viewing Democrats unfavorably, and 28% view Democrats favorably and Republicans unfavorably [12]. Independents who do not lean towards either party are the most likely to hold negative views of both parties at 37%, while 22% view both parties favorably [12].  Currently, 11% of independents without a lean favor the Democratic Party and 9% have a favorable view of the Republican party [12].  In conclusion,  while independents are less likely than Republicans or Democrats to favor one party over the other,  a plurality of independents hold unfavorable views of both major parties.

Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to Democrats. [12]  Around 82% of Republicans believe China did a bad job managing the outbreak, with a stark 61% stating they did a "very bad" job. [9] ![The image is a bar chart displaying survey results on people's perceptions of something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographic groups.](image1) In contrast, only 54% of Democrats share the sentiment of China's mismanagement. [9] This partisan divide extends to how both groups perceive the impact of the outbreak on U.S.-China relations. A significant 71% of Republicans believe that the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic, even if it negatively affects economic relations. [11] This view is less prevalent among Democrats, with only 37% supporting such action. [11] Conversely, a larger percentage of Democrats, at 50%, prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means potentially overlooking China's role in the outbreak. ![The image contains survey data visualized in a bar and pie chart about U.S. public opinion on U.S.-China relations and the role of China in the coronavirus outbreak.](image5) These contrasting viewpoints highlight the significant partisan gap in perceptions of China's actions and the implications for bilateral relations. Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations than Democrats.

A 2020 Pew Research Center survey found that [8] Republicans were significantly more likely than Democrats to hold negative views of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.  Specifically, 82% of Republicans believed that China did a bad job handling the outbreak, compared to 54% of Democrats [4]. This partisan divide was also evident in views on China's initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan, with 73% of Republicans attributing a great deal of blame to China, compared to 38% of Democrats [2]. ![The image is a horizontal bar graph showing the distribution of responses to a survey or question.](image2) This difference in perception extends back several years, as shown in a trend from 2005 to 2020, where Republicans consistently held more negative views of China compared to Democrats [4]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends from 2005 to 2020. The graph indicates changes over time in percentages or scores associated with these groups.](image4) Overall, Republicans are more critical of China's handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and this difference in perception has been consistent over time.

A Pew Research Center survey [2] revealed that a significant majority of Americans, around three-quarters [9], believe that the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan substantially contributed to its global spread. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with 73% attributing a great deal of blame to China's early response [9]. This finding is further corroborated by  ![The image is a horizontal bar graph showing the distribution of responses to a survey or question.](image5) which shows that 51% of respondents believe China’s initial handling of the outbreak was "a great deal" to blame for the global spread of the virus. 

This sentiment translates into a desire for accountability, as half of Americans believe that the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it negatively impacts economic relations [7]. This stance is more prevalent among Republicans, with 71% supporting this view compared to 37% of Democrats [3].  ![The image contains survey data visualized in a bar and pie chart about U.S. public opinion on U.S.-China relations and the role of China in the coronavirus outbreak.](image4) further supports this, indicating a 50% preference for prioritizing strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role, contrasting with the 38% who agree with holding China responsible.

The survey also highlights a clear partisan divide in how Americans perceive China's handling of the outbreak and the appropriate response [2]. Republicans are considerably more critical of China's actions, with 82% viewing their handling of the coronavirus as bad, in contrast to 54% of Democrats [11].  ![The image is a bar chart displaying survey results on people's perceptions of something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographic groups.](image2) reinforces this partisan divide, with 82% of Republicans/Leaning Republicans perceiving it as "Bad" compared to 54% of Democrats/Leaning Democrats. This difference in opinion extends to their outlook on U.S.-China relations, with Republicans more inclined towards a tougher approach compared to Democrats [2]. 

In conclusion, Americans are divided on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and its implications for U.S.-China relations, with Republicans generally holding more critical views and favoring a tougher stance than Democrats.
