Americans' views of China have grown increasingly negative in recent years, with [7] around three-quarters (73%) of Americans holding an unfavorable view of China today – the most negative reading in 15 years. Americans' views of China have soured in recent years, reaching a 15-year high of 73% unfavorable in 2020. [12] This negative sentiment has been on the rise, increasing by 26 percentage points since 2018 and showing a consistent upward trend. [12]  This trend is reflected across different age groups, although the increase is most pronounced among older Americans. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over time from 2005 to 2020. It tracks three age groups: "18-29," "30-49," and "50 and older." Each age group is represented by a different colored line.](image8) While negative views have grown across all age groups, those aged 50 and older exhibit significantly more negative views (81%) compared to those aged 30-49 (71%) and those under 30 (56%). [7]  This negative shift in opinion is particularly notable among older Americans, with a 10 percentage point increase since March. [7] Political affiliations also play a role in shaping opinions towards China.  ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image6)  Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views of China (83%) compared to Democrats (68%). [9]  This partisan gap has widened in recent months, with negative views among Republicans increasing by 11 percentage points compared to a 6-point increase among Democrats. [8]  The increase in negative opinions of China is widespread across different age groups and political affiliations in the United States, with older Americans and Republicans showing the most significant shifts.

Around two-thirds  $(64\%)$   of Americans believe that China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak, with   $43\%$  saying China has done a very bad job [8]. ![The image is a bar chart displaying survey results on people's perceptions of something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographic groups.](image4) This negative perception of China's pandemic response is more pronounced among older Americans, with  $73\%$  of those aged 50 and older criticizing China's handling, compared to  $59\%$  of those aged 30 to 49 and  $54\%$  of those under 30 [12].  This age-related disparity is mirrored in the overall unfavorable views of China, with  $81\%$  of Americans aged 50 and older holding negative views, significantly higher than the  $71\%$  of those aged 30 to 49 and  $56\%$  of those under 30 [6]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image5) This trend of increasingly negative views of China among older Americans has been evident in recent months [5].  ![This image is a line graph showing trends over time from 2005 to 2020. It tracks three age groups: "18-29," "30-49," and "50 and older." Each age group is represented by a different colored line.](image6)  Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more critical of China's pandemic response than their Democrat counterparts, with  $82\%$  versus  $54\%$  believing China mishandled the situation [10]. This partisan divide extends to general perceptions of China, with  $83\%$  of Republicans holding unfavorable views compared to  $68\%$  of Democrats [11].  ![The image is a line graph showing trends from 2005 to 2020. It tracks two groups: **Rep/Lean Rep** (in red) and **Dem/Lean Dem** (in blue).](image3)  In conclusion, older Americans and Republicans tend to have more negative views of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, consistent with their generally less favorable views of China in recent years.

Around two-thirds of Americans, or  $(64\%)$, believe that China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak, with  $43\%$  stating that China has done a very bad job. [11] This sentiment towards China's handling of the pandemic is reflected across different age groups and political affiliations, however, the intensity of these criticisms varies.  Older people are more critical, with $73\%$ of those ages 50 and older finding fault in China’s pandemic response. [12] In contrast, only  $59\%$   of those 30 to 49 and   $54\%$   of those under 30 share the same view. [9] ![The image is a bar chart displaying survey results on people's perceptions of something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographic groups.](image2) Looking at political affiliations,  Republicans and Republican-leaning  independents are significantly more likely than  Democrats and Democratic leaners to say China  has done a bad job dealing with the  coronavirus:  $82\%$   vs.  $54\%$, respectively. [12]  ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image3) Republicans are about twice as likely to think China has  done a very bad job ($61\%$  vs.  $30\%$). [12]  Furthermore,  $73\%$ of Republicans  believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a  great deal to its spread, compared with  $38\%$ of Democrats. [5]  ![The image is a horizontal bar graph showing the distribution of responses to a survey or question.](image6) In conclusion, older Americans and Republicans are more critical of China's handling of COVID-19.

[2] In the U.S., Republicans favor Israel as a foreign policy partner more than Democrats (26% vs. 9%), while Democrats prioritize Canada and Mexico. ![The image is a comparative bar graph showing the percentages of Americans and Germans who view certain countries as important partners.](image2) However, both parties view Germany similarly, ranking it fifth in importance. [3] Although both Democrats and Republicans consider Germany a top foreign policy partner, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel.  [11] This difference in preference extends to choosing between a close relationship with Russia or Germany. Democrats overwhelmingly (66%) favor Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans, with 31% of Republicans preferring Russia over 21% of Democrats.  [12] Democrats are more inclined towards greater cooperation with Germany, while in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more open to increased cooperation with the U.S. than those aligned with the Greens and the SPD. In conclusion, political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly shape preferences for foreign policy partners and desired levels of cooperation.

Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. ![The image compares American and German opinions on increasing the influence of several countries, including Russia. ](image1) This difference in opinion is particularly noticeable when comparing preferences for close relationships with Russia or Germany. While 61% of Americans favor closer ties with Germany over Russia, only 39% of Germans prefer the U.S. over Russia.  ![The image shows that 61% of Americans prefer closer ties with Germany over Russia while only 39% of Germans prefer the U.S. over Russia.](image8)  This difference is also apparent when looking at East and West Germany, with East Germans showing a stronger preference for Russia [10].  ![The image highlights that 38% of East Germans prefer Russia compared to 23% who favor the U.S.](image6) Political affiliations further highlight these differences. Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor cooperation with Russia than Democrats (41% vs. 32%) [3].  However, in Germany, it's the supporters of CDU/CSU who show a greater inclination towards increased cooperation with the U.S. compared to those aligned with the Greens and the SPD [9].

When considering China, Germans are about twice as likely as Americans to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%) [8].  ![The image shows that 50% of Germans prefer closer ties with the U.S. over China compared to only 24% who favor China.](image8)  This contrasts with the near-equal split among Americans, with 44% preferring China and 41% preferring Germany. Notably, younger Americans demonstrate a stronger inclination towards a close relationship with China compared to older Americans [7]. ![The image shows that 58% of Chinese respondents aged 18-29 prefer closer ties with China, compared to only 32% of Germans in the same age group.](image4)

In conclusion, Germans are more likely to favor cooperation with Russia but less inclined towards closer ties with China compared to Americans. These preferences are further influenced by political affiliations in both countries, highlighting the multifaceted nature of international relations.

[1] states that there are slight partisan differences in the U.S. on choosing a close relationship with Russia or Germany: 66% of Democrats prefer Germany while only 21% prefer Russia, compared to 57% and 31% respectively for Republicans. This difference in preference for closer ties with Germany or Russia between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. is further illustrated in ![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding two different questions.](image2). When looking specifically at Russia, [11] shows that Republicans in the U.S. (41%) are more likely to prefer increased cooperation with Russia than Democrats (32%).  In Germany, those who support CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and SPD [6]. ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany.](image6) provides a visual representation of the party alignment percentages in both the U.S. and Germany.  Furthermore, [8] states that Conservative Americans are more likely to view Russia favorably than American liberals. This partisan divide regarding Russia is also present in Germany, with those on the right of the ideological spectrum being more likely to view Russia favorably, though the divide is less stark than in the U.S. [8]. 

In conclusion, political party preferences in the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with right-leaning individuals and parties showing a greater inclination towards collaboration.

Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor cooperation with Russia than Democrats (31% vs. 21%) [3]. This is also reflected in the observation that increased cooperation with Russia is a more common preference among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%) [8]. ![The image is a comparison chart showing the percentage of Americans and Germans who think that various countries should have "Less" or "More" influence.](image5) In Germany, there are notable differences between supporters of different parties regarding U.S.-German cooperation [10]. ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany. The chart uses horizontal lines to represent a 0-100% scale for party alignment or approval.](image6)  Supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [11]. This aligns with the finding that conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely than American liberals and Germans on the left to view Russia favorably [6]. Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes towards cooperation with Russia, with right-leaning groups showing more favorability.

When asked which country holds the mantle of the world's leading economic power, Americans and Germans provide contrasting perspectives [3]. While half of Americans confidently proclaim the U.S. as the economic leader, a considerable portion $(32\%)$ points to China's rising influence [3]. Conversely, a majority of Germans $(53\%)$ perceive China as the dominant economic force, with only $24\%$ naming the U.S. [3]. This difference in perception is starkly illustrated in ![The image compares percentages of Americans and Germans who consider certain countries important partners, highlighting Germans' higher regard for the U.S. compared to Americans' view of Germany.](image1), where Germans are significantly more likely than Americans to view the U.S. as an important partner. This suggests a potential disparity in how each country perceives its own global economic standing.

Further highlighting the divide in viewpoints,  a significant 7 percentage point increase in positive sentiment towards U.S.- German relations has been observed among Americans since 2017, with three-quarters now stating the relationship is in good shape [10]. This stands in contrast to the German perspective, where only half of the population shares a desire for increased cooperation with the U.S. [11]. 

Beyond the economic sphere, differing viewpoints extend to international relationships. Germans generally hold more favorable opinions of the EU, Russia, China, the UN, and NATO compared to their American counterparts [6]. ![Approval ratings for EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO from U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany, showing Germany consistently higher.](image2) illustrates this difference, particularly regarding the EU, where a striking 18% gap exists between German and American approval. While approximately seven in ten Germans express support for the EU, only about half of Americans share this sentiment [6].  This suggests a potential difference in values and priorities when it comes to international collaborations and alliances.

In conclusion, Americans and Germans hold differing views on the leading economic power, with Americans favoring the U.S. and Germans leaning towards China. Additionally, their perspectives on international relationships, especially regarding entities like the EU, reveal a consistent trend where Germans exhibit more favorable opinions compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans hold differing views on which country is the world’s leading economic power [7]. While half of Americans believe it to be the U.S.,  Germans are more likely to name China (53%) ![The image appears to be a bar chart comparing various percentages related to the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image1). This difference in perception likely stems from China's growing global economic influence and perhaps a difference in how each country perceives the economic impact of the U.S. and China on their respective nations.

These differing viewpoints extend to international organizations as well [10]. Although both countries generally view the UN and NATO favorably, Germans hold more positive opinions of these organizations than Americans. This is particularly evident in their views on the EU, which enjoys significantly higher favorability among Germans (69%) than Americans (51%) ![The image is a comparative bar chart showing approval ratings of five international entities (EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO) from the perspectives of three groups: U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany. Each group is represented by a different color: blue for the U.S., gray for the median, and green for Germany.](image5). 

Ideology plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions [11]. Conservative Americans and Germans tend to view Russia more favorably than their liberal counterparts, while the opposite is true for the UN and EU. This suggests that political leanings, influenced by factors like historical context and party affiliations, contribute to how individuals perceive international entities. For instance, the history of the Cold War and the EU's role in shaping modern Europe could factor into these differing opinions.

In conclusion, Americans and Germans diverge in their views of leading economic powers and international organizations, with these perceptions largely influenced by factors such as perceived economic impact and political ideologies.

Americans are far more likely than Germans to believe that the use of military force is sometimes necessary [5]. About eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use force to maintain order in the world, yet only about half of Germans agree [9].  This difference in opinion is also reflected in their views on defense spending. ![The image is a comparative bar chart that depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image6) While half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current level of defense spending, there is a significant drop in the percentage of Americans who support increased defense spending by European allies from 2017 to 2019 [3]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem." ](image1) This shift in opinion is evident across both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S [2]. In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain defense spending, with about four-in-ten taking each view [7]. Despite these differences on security issues, young people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship [11]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing age group differences in percentages between the U.S. and Germany. The percentages seem to describe some aspect, possibly agreeability or support, across different age groups. ](image3) In the U.S., 82% of people ages 18 to 29 view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those ages 65 and older [11]. Similarly, in Germany, four-in-ten young people say relations with the U.S. are good, compared with only 31% of those 65 and older [11]. In conclusion, Americans are more likely than Germans to see military force as necessary and favor increased defense spending, while young people in both countries hold more positive views on U.S.-Germany relations.

Americans are more likely than Germans to believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain world order [3]. This difference in opinion is reflected in their views on defense spending. While half of Americans believe that U.S. allies in Europe should maintain their current levels of defense spending, a notable shift from 2017 when 45% of Americans felt their allies should increase spending, Germans are more divided on the issue [12].  `![{Germans' opinion on whether Germany should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense over the years}](image5)`  Germans are split between increasing or maintaining current spending levels on national defense [2].

This difference in opinion is also apparent in views on NATO. Six-in-ten Americans believe the U.S. should use military force to defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, while an equal percentage of Germans disagree [11]. `![Opinions of people from the U.S. and Germany on an unspecified issue about whether something should or should not be done.](image3)` This difference is further highlighted by the fact that 85% of Americans believe that U.S. military bases in Germany are important to U.S. security interests, while only half of Germans agree [8].  `![Comparing the perceived importance of an unspecified subject between respondents from the U.S. and Germany.](image2)` 

In conclusion, Americans are generally more supportive of military intervention and defense spending than Germans.

Americans' views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues differ significantly along party lines. Republicans tend to favor the U.S. focusing on its own problems rather than engaging in international affairs. As stated in [7], about three-quarters of Republicans, regardless of their ideological leaning (conservative or moderate/liberal), believe the U.S. should prioritize its own issues. This sentiment is reflected in ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentages of various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image5), where a significantly higher percentage of Republicans support this view compared to Democrats.

Furthermore, there's a clear divide in opinion based on education levels. [6] indicates individuals with higher education levels tend to be more supportive of the U.S. engaging in global issues. For instance, 60% of postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries. This trend is also evident in ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentages of various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image5), where a higher percentage of individuals with postgraduate and college-level education support international engagement compared to those with some college or high school education.  In contrast, [3] highlights the contrasting view among Democrats, with a majority believing the U.S. should help other countries, particularly among liberal Democrats. This difference in opinion based on political affiliation and education level demonstrates the complex and multifaceted perspectives surrounding U.S. involvement in global issues. 

In conclusion, Republicans and those with lower education levels are more likely to prioritize domestic issues over global engagement, whereas Democrats, particularly those with higher education, show greater support for international involvement.

Around two-thirds of Americans believe that China did not handle the COVID-19 pandemic well. [2] This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, especially Conservative Republicans, with eight out of ten holding this view. [9]  ![This image is a bar chart showing survey results regarding people's evaluation as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent." The categories include racial groups (White, Black, Hispanic), age groups, educational attainment, and political affiliations with subcategories of conservatism and liberalism. While 47% of adults overall believe the U.S. response was good or excellent, this view is held by 71% of Republicans and only 27% of Democrats. [6] This partisan gap is significant, with 73% of Democrats criticizing the U.S. response compared to 71% of Republicans praising it. [7]  Interestingly, education level plays a role in how Americans perceive their own country's response to the pandemic.  A higher level of education correlates with a more critical view of the U.S. response, with two-thirds of those with postgraduate degrees rating the U.S. response poorly.  [10] In conclusion, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively, while higher education levels correlate with a more negative perception of the U.S. response, regardless of political affiliation.

Americans' views on the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are sharply divided along partisan lines [10].  Republicans are far more likely than Democrats to say the U.S. has done a good job handling the outbreak (71% vs. 27%) [3]. This partisan gap is also evident in the assessment of China's response, with Republicans being much more critical [9].  ![This image is a bar chart showing survey results regarding people's evaluation as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent." The categories include racial groups (White, Black, Hispanic), age groups, educational attainment, and political affiliations with subcategories of conservatism and liberalism. Each group is represented by two bars indicating the percentage of each evaluation. While a majority of Americans believe the U.S. can learn from other countries [5], Republicans who believe this are more likely to rate other countries' pandemic responses favorably compared to Republicans who think the U.S. has little to learn [2].  This suggests that political affiliation influences not only the perception of the U.S.'s performance but also the openness to learning from other countries. ![The image is a bar chart showing the perceptions of some variable (unspecified here) by different demographic groups. Americans' views on the U.S.'s capacity to learn from other countries in managing the coronavirus outbreak exhibit a stark partisan divide. While a significant majority (63%) believe the U.S. can learn from other nations [1], this sentiment is much stronger among Democrats than Republicans. A mere 28% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view, contrasting sharply with the 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents who believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from the international response [5]. This partisan gap is particularly pronounced among those who believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" from other countries, with 67% of liberal Democrats holding this view compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [8]. 

![This image is a chart showing the trust levels among different political groups for the WHO (World Health Organization), EU (European Union), and the Chinese government.](image3)

This partisan divide extends to trust in international organizations as well.  For instance, 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO, compared to a mere 27% of conservative Republicans [2]. 
![This image is a horizontal bar chart showing survey results on the level of trust or influence in three entities: the EU, WHO, and the Chinese government. ](image1)
This trend of heightened trust in international organizations among Democrats is mirrored in their views on the EU as well [10].  In conclusion, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries' handling of the coronavirus and to trust information from international organizations like the WHO and EU.

A Pew Research Center survey reveals a significant partisan divide in how Americans perceive the role of the U.S. in global affairs. [7] Republicans are increasingly likely to believe that the U.S. is overly involved in addressing global challenges, with a notable increase from 52% in 2013 to 62% in 2020. ![The graph showcases a rising trend among Republicans who believe the U.S. does "Too much" in addressing global challenges.](image1) This contrasts sharply with Democrats, who show a consistent decrease in holding this view, dropping from 48% in 2013 to 26% in 2020.  ![The graph illustrates the declining trend among Democrats who believe the U.S. does "Too much" in addressing global challenges. ](image3) This partisan gap extends to perceptions of U.S. influence following the coronavirus outbreak. Republicans are increasingly likely to advocate for a more inward-looking approach, while Democrats remain more supportive of international engagement. In conclusion, Republicans are becoming more likely to believe that the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while Democrats are more likely to support an internationally engaged U.S.

Americans' views on the U.S.'s role in the world are divided, with  $60\%$  believing the U.S. should prioritize its own problems and let other countries manage their own affairs [4]. Americans express significant concerns about China's actions on the world stage, particularly regarding issues like cyberattacks [12], the loss of U.S. jobs to China [6], and China's growing military power [6]. These concerns are reflected in their views on the severity of these issues, with a large majority considering them serious problems for the U.S.  ![{Different concerns about China with percentage}](image7). For instance, 91% of Americans view cyberattacks from China as a serious problem, followed closely by concerns about China's military power and trade deficit with the U.S. ![{Different concerns about China with percentage}](image7). This apprehension towards China's actions translates into a more nuanced view of President Biden's ability to handle these complex issues. Despite generally positive views on Biden's foreign policy, his approval rating specifically concerning China is noticeably lower. ![{Confidence levels in Biden to deal with global issues including China}](image6) While a combined 53% of Americans believe he can somewhat or very effectively deal with China, this is the lowest approval rating compared to other foreign policy areas like improving relationships with allies (67% approval) or dealing with terrorism (60% approval) ![{Confidence levels in Biden to deal with global issues including China}](image6).  This suggests that while Americans acknowledge the seriousness of the challenges posed by China, they are less certain about Biden's capacity to navigate this complex geopolitical landscape effectively. Americans are significantly concerned about China's actions, particularly in areas like cyberattacks and military power, and this is reflected in their somewhat reserved confidence in Biden's ability to handle these issues effectively.

Americans express substantial concern when asked about eight specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship. About three-quarters or  more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [12]. Still, four problems stand out for being ones that half or more describe as  very  serious: cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to  China, China’s growing military power and  China’s policies on human rights [12]. ![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China. It categorizes concerns into two levels: "Very serious" and "Somewhat serious", alongside the total percentage for each concern.](image8)  Around half of Americans have confidence Biden will be able to deal effectively with China $(53\%)$ [4]. However, this is the issue among six tested in which Americans have the least confidence in Biden [4]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people who believe in varying degrees of effectiveness (from "Not at all" to "Very") on different foreign policy and global issues.](image4) When it comes to Biden's approval on dealing with China, partisan differences are particularly large  [7]. Whereas $83\%$ of Democrats and those who lean toward the Democratic Party have confidence in Biden on China, only $19\%$ of Republicans and leaners say the same [7]. ![The image appears to be a bar graph showing levels of confidence among different demographic groups.](image7) Women $(59\%)$ are more confident than men $(48\%)$ in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China [10]. Black $(82\%)$ and Hispanic adults $(70\%)$ also express more confidence than White adults $(43\%)$ [10]. Those with a college degree expect Biden will be able to deal effectively with China at a higher rate than those with less schooling ($60\%$ vs. $50\%$, respectively) [10].  Americans are most concerned about cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights, and they have the least confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China compared to other foreign policy issues, with significant partisan and demographic differences in levels of confidence.

A 2021 Pew Research Center survey revealed a significant shift in American attitudes toward China since 2018, with negative sentiment increasing substantially [7, 9]. This shift is evident in the rising number of Americans who hold "cold" feelings towards China, increasing from 46% in 2018 to 67% in 2021 [7]. ![The image shows a pair of line graphs comparing opinions from 2018 to 2021 about limiting China’s influence and feelings towards China.](image4) This negative sentiment is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with 62% reporting "very cold" feelings towards China, a 31-point increase from 2018 [3].  The driving forces behind this change are multifaceted, with a confluence of economic, political, and human rights concerns shaping American views.

One major concern is China's economic power and influence.  Americans perceive China's economic practices as detrimental to the U.S. economy and unfair to workers [4].  ![The image is a bar chart depicting public perceptions or opinions related to China.](image1)  Further exacerbating these concerns are growing anxieties over job losses to China and China's increasing technological prowess [8].  ![The image is a series of line graphs that show the change in percentage from 2020 to 2021 on various issues related to China.](image6)  Beyond economic anxieties, Americans express significant apprehension regarding China's human rights record, with many citing it as a top concern [10, 11].  The treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, in particular, weighs heavily on the minds of many Americans [5, 10].  

Adding to these concerns, Americans view China's political system with suspicion and perceive its growing military power as a threat [1, 8]. ![The image is a bar chart depicting public perceptions or opinions related to China.](image1) This has led to nearly half of Americans (48%) supporting the prioritization of limiting China's power and influence in foreign policy [6].  ![The image shows a pair of line graphs comparing opinions from 2018 to 2021 about limiting China’s influence and feelings towards China.](image4) 

In conclusion, from 2018 to 2021, American perceptions of China have declined significantly due to concerns about China's economic practices, human rights record, and growing global influence.

Americans hold several key concerns regarding China, with many stemming from the perception that China's growing global influence negatively impacts the U.S.. These anxieties intensified between 2020 and 2021, as illustrated by the escalating percentages of Americans expressing serious concerns about cyberattacks originating from China, China's human rights policies, job displacement attributed to China, and the increasing military and technological prowess of China. ![The image depicts the growth of concerns from 2020 to 2021 regarding China's cyberattacks, human rights policies, job displacement, and military and technological advancements.](image2) Notably, these worries extend to China's handling of global issues, with a significant 79% of Americans disapproving of China's approach to climate change [6]. This distrust is further highlighted by the fact that two-thirds of Americans view the current economic relationship with China as unfavorable [10]. 

The roots of these concerns run deep, with a majority of Americans perceiving inherent differences between the Chinese people and their government. While recognizing the individuality of Chinese citizens, many harbor reservations about the Chinese government, viewing it as a totalitarian regime with expansionist ambitions [5]. This sentiment is particularly evident in the context of Hong Kong, where China's actions have solidified this perception.  Furthermore, there's a clear partisan divide in how these concerns translate into policy preferences.  Republicans are more inclined to advocate for a hardened economic stance against China, potentially even at the cost of economic ties. They are also more prone to perceive China as a direct adversary rather than a competitor or partner, and are more likely to endorse restrictions on Chinese students studying in the U.S. ![The image shows that Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor a tougher economic approach towards China, view China as an enemy, support limitations on Chinese students studying in the U.S., and hold unfavorable views of China.](image1) 

Despite these concerns, a significant 70% of Americans prioritize the advancement of human rights in China, even if it implies compromising economic relations [4]. This suggests a complex interplay between economic anxieties and moral considerations when it comes to China. Although a slight majority (53%) express confidence in President Biden's ability to navigate the complexities of U.S.-China relations, this confidence is noticeably lower compared to his handling of other foreign policy issues. ![The image presents a comparison of confidence levels regarding President Biden's handling of different international issues, with confidence in his management of China being lower than other issues.](image6) Interestingly, while Americans harbor significant concerns about China, their top-of-mind associations with the nation revolve around human rights and the economy. ![The image shows that human rights and the economy are the most frequent topics that Americans associate with China.](image8)

In conclusion, the key concerns of Americans regarding China are multifaceted, encompassing anxieties about economic competition, human rights violations, growing Chinese influence, and a perceived threat to U.S. interests, with these concerns growing more pronounced over time and revealing a complex interplay of economic, political, and moral considerations.

Latinos are broadly optimistic about their economic prospects. Fully eight-in-ten Latinos $(81\%)$ say they expect their family’s financial situation will improve in the coming year, a 14 percentage point increase since 2008 [4]. Looking ahead, optimism about their family’s future economic prospects has risen faster among Latinos than in the population as a whole. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year is up 14 percentage points, from $67\%$ in 2008 – during the Great Recession – and in 2011 to $81\%$ in 2015. By contrast, the share of all Americans who share this optimistic view of their family’s pocketbook prospects rose 6 percentage points to $61\%$ during that time [5]. ![The image shows a line graph that compares the percentage of favorable opinions between Hispanic and general public from 2004 to 2015.](image5) This analysis shows that all of the increase among Hispanics in perceptions about their family’s finances has occurred since 2011 when, two years after the Great Recession officially ended, $67\%$ of Latinos said they expected their finances to improve “a lot” or “some.” That share then grew by 6 percentage points to $73\%$ in 2012, and now stands at $81\%$ [12]. Since 2008, most Latino subgroups  more optimistic about their finances [6].  ![The image shows a bar chart comparing the percentage of various demographic groups' support or approval from 2008 and 2015.](image7) The gains in economic optimism are similarly large among Latinos ages 30 to 49 and 50 to 64 (+16 points for each group) [1]. However, as with perceptions of their current financial condition, older Latinos were significantly less upbeat about their short-term economic future than were younger and middle-aged Hispanics [2]. Financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has increased significantly from 2008 to 2015, surpassing the optimism observed in the general population.

Hispanics who have a positive view of their current financial situation are significantly more likely to expect their family's financial situation to improve over the next 12 months. [4] ![The chart displays the percentage of respondents expecting their financial conditions to improve or worsen based on their current financial situation.](image8) Hispanics place a high value on their children's financial well-being, with a majority expecting their children to have better financial security than themselves. [5]  This optimism is particularly evident among those with a high school education, with 79% believing their children will be better off. [10] However, educational attainment doesn't drastically alter this outlook, as a similar proportion (71%) of those with less than a high school education share the same sentiment. [10] ![The chart illustrates the perceived economic well-being of various Hispanic demographics, including education levels, compared to a previous time.](image3)  Hispanics, regardless of their current financial status or educational background, remain largely optimistic about their children's financial future. Hispanics with a more favorable current financial situation are more likely to be optimistic about their children's financial prospects, and while there are some variations based on education level, the overall sentiment remains positive.

Latinos have become significantly more optimistic about their finances and future prospects since the 2008-2010 recession [1]. This positive outlook is reflected in the growing percentage of Latinos who anticipate improvements in their family's financial situation.  ![The image is a line graph comparing the attitudes or opinions of Hispanic individuals and the general public from 2004 to 2015.](image4) This optimism is particularly pronounced among younger Latinos under 30, with a 13-point increase in those expecting their financial situation to improve [8]. Despite these optimistic perceptions, the economic reality for Latinos presents a more complex picture. While median household income for Hispanics has remained largely unchanged since the Great Recession at $42,491 [5], their unemployment rate, although consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates, has shown improvement.  ![The image is a line graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015.](image7)  The unemployment rate for Latinos fell from 12.8% in early 2010 to 6.4% by late 2015 [6].  ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image2) However, it's worth noting that this rate still exceeds the levels observed in 2006 [6]. In conclusion, while Latinos are significantly more optimistic about their financial well-being, their unemployment rate, though improved, remains a concern.

The unemployment rate for Hispanics has historically been higher than that of non-Hispanics. As shown in ![The image is a line graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015.](image8), in 2000 the unemployment rate for Hispanics was 5.8% compared to 3.8% for non-Hispanics. Despite a decrease in unemployment rates since the Great Recession for both groups [8], the gap persists, with Hispanic unemployment at 6.4% and non-Hispanic at 4.8% in 2015. This disparity in employment directly impacts the stark difference in income and wealth accumulation between the two groups. ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image2) shows that the median household income for Hispanics in 2014 was $42,500, significantly lower than the $53,700 for all U.S. households.  Furthermore, while the median household wealth for all U.S. households in 2013 was $81,400, it was only $13,700 for Hispanic households. This disparity is also reflected in poverty rates, with Hispanics experiencing a much higher poverty rate of 23.6% in 2014 compared to 14.8% for all U.S. households. Despite these challenges, Hispanics maintain a more optimistic view of their financial situation [6]. While only 38% of the general public viewed their financial situation positively in 2011, this figure was 73% for Hispanics. This difference in perception could be attributed to factors such as increased optimism about future economic conditions and upward mobility for their children [4]. ![The image is a pie chart that indicates how people feel about their well-being compared to a prior period.](image1) reveals that a significant 72% of Latinos believe their children will be better off financially than themselves.  

In conclusion, despite experiencing higher unemployment rates and significant income and wealth disparities, the Hispanic population exhibits a more positive outlook on their financial situation compared to non-Hispanics, potentially influenced by their optimism about future economic prospects and their children's upward mobility.

While both Hispanic and non-Hispanic workers saw increased unemployment rates during the recession, Hispanics have consistently faced higher unemployment rates from 2000 to 2015. ![The image is a line graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015.](image4) In 2014, the median income for Hispanic households was $42,491, essentially unchanged since the Great Recession. [8] The income disparity is evident when comparing Hispanic households to all U.S. households, where the median income is noticeably higher. ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image5) Although the poverty rate among Hispanic households decreased from a peak of 26.5% in 2010, the 2014 rate of 23.6% remained above pre-recession levels. [8]  Comparatively, all U.S. households experienced a significantly lower poverty rate at 14.8% during the same year. ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image5) The disparity in wealth accumulation is particularly striking. While all households saw a decline in median net worth from 2005 to 2013, Hispanic households experienced a significantly steeper decline. ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image5)  Hispanic households had the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 compared to other racial or ethnic groups, and this downward trend persisted even after the recession, unlike white households whose net worth began to recover. [8]  From 2000 to 2015, Hispanic households faced more severe economic challenges than all U.S. households, characterized by higher unemployment, lower income, a higher poverty rate, and a greater decline in wealth.

Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have seen a notable increase between 2008 and 2015. Specifically, four in ten Latinos described their personal finances as "excellent" or "good" in 2015, a 17 percentage point increase from 2008 when only 23% shared a similarly positive view [10]. This upward trend in positive financial outlook among Latinos contrasts with the stagnant view of the general American population, whose positive perception of their finances remained relatively unchanged during the same period [10]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over time for two groups: the "General public" and "Hispanic." The y-axis represents a percentage scale from 0% to 60%, while the x-axis covers the years from 2004 to 2015.](image5) While there have been improvements in how Latinos perceive their personal financial situations, the picture is more nuanced when considering family income relative to the cost of living. In 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos reported their family income was not keeping pace with the cost of living [11]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living among Hispanic, White, and Black adults in 2014 and 2015.](image1) This sentiment remained consistent from the previous year [4]. This suggests that although Latinos have experienced an overall improved sense of personal financial well-being, concerns about income struggling to keep up with living expenses persist. In conclusion, from 2008 to 2015, Latinos experienced an increase in positive perceptions of their personal finances, while their views on family income relative to the cost of living remained relatively unchanged.

![This pie chart segments the older adult population by internet and social media usage.](image1)  While older adults are less likely to use the internet than the general population, those who do use it tend to integrate it into their daily routines [7]. ![The bar chart illustrates the technology adoption disparity between adults aged 65 and over and the general adult population.](image2) However, there is a significant difference in technology adoption rates between older adults and the general population. This suggests that socioeconomic factors and age play a significant role in internet usage among seniors. Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and another 11% go online three to five times per week [1]. ![This bar chart provides a visual representation of the percentage of internet users within various age groups who engage in online activities daily or almost daily, as well as those who go online 3-5 times per week.](image4) Seniors who own smartphones or have broadband at home tend to use the internet even more frequently [7]. In conclusion, while internet usage among seniors is lower than the general population, those who use it often make it a part of their daily routine, with usage declining significantly after age 75.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors, while steadily increasing, are still well below the national average [12]. For example, while 86% of all U.S. adults use the internet, only 59% of seniors report going online [1].  This digital divide is further evident in broadband adoption, with only 47% of seniors having a high-speed connection at home, compared to much higher rates among the general population [9]. 

![This image shows a line graph depicting trends over time from 2000 to 2013. It compares two groups: "All Adults 18+" and "65+".](image5)

Several factors contribute to this disparity, particularly age, education, and income.  Internet use and broadband adoption among seniors each fall off notably starting at approximately age 75 [3]. For instance, while 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, this number plummets to 37% for those aged 80 and older [6].  This trend is mirrored in broadband adoption rates as well [6]. Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors, on the other hand, use the internet and broadband at rates approaching—or even exceeding—the general population [5].

![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image6)

Education and income levels also play a significant role.  Seniors with a college degree boast an 87% internet usage rate and 76% broadband adoption rate, while those with a high school education or less lag significantly behind at 40% and 27% respectively [6]. Affluent and well-educated seniors  adopt the internet and broadband at  substantially higher rates than those with  lower levels of income and educational  attainment [8].  This disparity is evident across all age groups within the senior population [7]. 

![The image is a bar chart comparing two groups: "All adults" and "65+" for two categories.](image1)

In conclusion, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are lower than the general population, with significant disparities related to age, education, and income.

Seniors, like any other demographic group, are not monolithic, and there are important distinctions in their tech adoption patterns [6]. Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and educational attainment [1]. Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching—or even exceeding—the general population [5].  ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image1) For example, slightly more than one third of those 80 years of age or older  use the internet, and just one in five members of this age group have a broadband connection at home [2]. Overall adoption levels are similar among seniors who have not attended college [2]. Smartphone ownership is fairly low along the entire age spectrum of the older adult population, but decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s, and becomes nearly non-existent among seniors in their 80s and beyond [11]. ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who own cell phones and smartphones, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image8)  Internet usage and smartphone ownership are significantly higher among seniors with higher levels of education.

Workers with higher levels of educational attainment tend to have more positive views of how technologies impact their jobs and careers [1]. For example, college graduates are more likely to report that technology makes their work more interesting  compared to those with a high school diploma or less [2].  ![This image is a bar chart comparing the effects of education level on work factors.](image5)  This difference in perception is also observed across a range of specific technologies, such as word processing software and email [12]. ![The image is a bar chart that shows the perceived impact of various technologies on different educational groups.](image3)  While many workers see the positive impacts of technologies like smartphones and software for managing schedules [5], there's a clear trend of higher education correlating with a more favorable view of technology's influence [10]. Looking ahead, a significant majority of Americans foresee driverless vehicles becoming prevalent within the next fifty years [8]. ![The image is a vertical bar chart divided into segments with corresponding numbers and labels to the right.](image1) In conclusion, higher educational attainment is associated with more positive perceptions of workforce technology, and driverless cars are expected to become increasingly common in the coming decades.

Workers generally express a mix of positive and negative views on how technology impacts their jobs and careers [6]. Interestingly, education level plays a significant role in these perceptions [8].  For example, a significantly higher percentage of workers with college degrees (90%) view word processing and spreadsheet software as having a positive impact on their careers, compared to 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [9].  This trend holds true for other technologies such as smartphones, email and social media, and software that manages schedules [9]. ![The image is a bar chart that shows the perceived impact of various technologies on different educational groups.](image5) This difference in perception also extends to how education levels influence feelings about job enrichment and career advancement opportunities.  ![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceived benefits of education level in terms of making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement.](image1)  When it comes to future technologies, a significant majority of Americans (94%) are aware of the development of driverless vehicles [1]. Two-thirds of the public predicts that driverless vehicles will be commonplace within 50 years, with 9% believing this will happen in the next decade [1]. Workers with higher levels of education  have more positive views of many  workplace technologies [4].  Workers express mixed views about the impact of  various workforce technologies [11]. In conclusion, individuals with higher education levels tend to view workplace technologies more positively and are more optimistic about the future adoption of technologies like driverless cars.

A significant majority of Americans, [1] 94%, are aware of the development of driverless vehicles, with two-thirds anticipating their prevalence within the next 50 years. This expectation for the future of automation contrasts with the current experiences of U.S. workers, who hold mixed views on the impact of technology on their jobs and careers [4]. While [1] 9% believe driverless vehicles will be commonplace within the next decade, the current generation of workforce technologies evokes varied responses. For instance, while [8] 70% of workers find word processing or spreadsheet software beneficial to their careers, only [8] 27% report a positive impact from industrial robots. This suggests that while the future of automation, exemplified by driverless vehicles, is met with high anticipation, the present reality of technological impact on work is more nuanced, with varying degrees of acceptance and apprehension, particularly concerning job displacement and career advancement, as indicated by [9]. Americans' levels of awareness about automation influence their perceptions of its implications for the future job market.  ![{The chart compares levels of realism, enthusiasm, and worry about a concept among people with different levels of familiarity.}](image1) Notably, those who have heard a lot about the concept find it to be more realistic. [1] This heightened awareness translates into a greater level of enthusiasm about the possibility of machines taking over human jobs. [6] However, increased familiarity doesn't diminish concerns.  [11] Regardless of their awareness level, a significant majority of Americans, ranging from 69% to 76%, express worry about a future where machines perform tasks once done by humans. [5]  ![{The chart depicts the distribution of responses regarding enthusiasm and worry about a concept.}](image2) This apprehension is further reflected in their anticipation of potential negative outcomes. [7] A significant 76% of Americans predict that widespread automation will exacerbate economic inequality. [4] This concern aligns with the finding that only 25% believe the economy will generate numerous well-paying jobs for humans in the face of advancing automation. [12] In contrast, a more substantial 75% anticipate this development being unlikely. [12] ![{The chart visualizes the anticipated impact of automation on various aspects of life and work.}](image6)  In conclusion, while Americans' awareness of automation increases their enthusiasm for its potential, it does not alleviate their substantial concerns about the negative implications for the job market and the economy.

[1, 12] When it comes to policies addressing workforce automation, Democrats and Republicans tend to agree on limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, and on allowing people to pay extra to interact with humans rather than machines in commercial settings.  However, there are stark differences in their views on a universal basic income and a national service program for workers displaced by automation. A significantly higher percentage of Democrats support both a universal basic income (77% vs. 38% of Republicans) and a national service program (66% vs. 46% of Republicans) in the event that machines displace a large share of human jobs [12]. ![This chart shows that support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is high across both parties, while support for a universal basic income and a national service program is much higher among Democrats.](image6)  The general public overwhelmingly favors limiting robots and computers to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans, with 85% of Americans in favor of this policy and 47% strongly favoring it [3, 11].  ![Public support is strong for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 47% strongly favoring and 38% favoring.](image1) In conclusion, while both parties agree on limiting machines to dangerous jobs, Democrats are more supportive of a universal basic income and a national service program as solutions for potential job displacement.

Americans are almost evenly split on whether the government or individuals should be responsible for caring for those displaced by automation, with 50% believing in government obligation and 49% emphasizing individual responsibility [1]. However, this viewpoint shifts dramatically when considering political affiliations.  ![This image is a bar chart illustrating public opinion on two issues related to automation and job displacement.](image8) Democrats are much more likely to support government intervention, with 65% favoring it, compared to only 30% of Republicans.  This partisan divide is less prominent regarding limiting automation in businesses. [2] Both Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) show relatively similar levels of support for such limitations. Interestingly, education levels reveal an inverse relationship with this particular issue. While 70% of individuals with high school diplomas or less support limiting automation, this number drops significantly to 41% among college graduates [6].  In conclusion, while political affiliations heavily influence opinions on government support for displaced workers,  both political affiliations and education levels shape beliefs about limiting automation in businesses.

Americans' opinions on how to address job displacement due to automation are divided along party lines, particularly regarding the role of government. [3] While a majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government should support workers displaced by automation, even if it means higher taxes, a similar percentage of Republicans (68%) think individuals should be responsible for their own well-being. ![The image is a bar chart illustrating public opinion on two issues related to automation and job displacement.](image1)  This partisan divide is also evident in support for specific policies. Democrats are significantly more likely to favor a universal basic income (77% vs. 38% of Republicans) and a national service program for displaced workers (66% vs. 46%). [9, 6] Interestingly, there is more agreement across party lines on other policy ideas. [4] For instance, a majority of both Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) support limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate. [9] However, the potential consequences of automation, such as increased inequality and difficulty finding meaningful work, are concerning to many Americans. ![The image is a bar graph that depicts survey results regarding the likelihood of various outcomes.](image4) In conclusion, political affiliations strongly influence American views on policies addressing workforce automation, especially regarding government intervention and social safety nets.

A small but significant portion of Americans, [3] $6\%$,  have already felt the impact of workforce automation through job losses or reduced pay/hours. ![This image is a bar chart showing the percentage of U.S. adults in different age groups who either lost a job or had their pay or hours reduced.](image4) Younger workers (ages 18-24) are more likely to have experienced this, hinting at a potential trend for the future. [1] This aligns with the sentiment that almost 6 in 10 workers believe their jobs will be predominantly automated within their lifetimes, a view twice as prevalent as those who haven't personally encountered automation's effects. 

Interestingly, while automation anxieties exist, there's a clear divide in how different education levels perceive technology's impact. [4, 5] Individuals with higher education tend to view technology favorably. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceived benefits of education level in terms of making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement.](image5)  Conversely, [2, 10] those with a high school diploma or less are less likely to find technology enriching or beneficial for career progression.  [9, 11] This discrepancy highlights a crucial aspect of the evolving workplace: those with higher education are more likely to benefit from technological advancements, while those with lower levels of education might face greater challenges.

In conclusion, while workers across all age groups and education levels express mixed feelings about technology's impact on jobs, younger workers and those with lower education levels are more likely to have experienced negative impacts, highlighting an important social and economic trend.

[2] Today’s workers have mixed feelings about the impact of technology on their jobs and careers. While some see these advancements positively, others view them as detrimental to their career growth. This difference in perception is particularly evident when considering the level of education attained. [11] Workers without a college degree are less likely to view technology favorably compared to their more educated counterparts. 
![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceived benefits of education level in terms of making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement.](image1) [12] College graduates are more likely to believe that technology has enriched their jobs, offering more engaging work and better career advancement opportunities. [1] This divide highlights the uneven impact of technology; those with higher education often benefit, while those without may feel its negative effects more acutely. Individuals with higher education levels tend to report that technology makes their work more interesting and provides greater opportunities for career advancement. Workers with a high school diploma or less reported that only 38% felt technology made work more interesting, in contrast to 64% with college degrees. In conclusion, perceptions of workforce automation and technology's impact vary significantly based on education level; those with higher education are more optimistic.

In  fact, similar shares of social media users ages 65 and older say they frequently see content on these  platforms that makes them feel amused   $\left(30\%\right)$   and angry   $({\it24\%})$  . ![The image is a horizontal dot plot displaying survey data about the emotional responses of different age groups to humorous or amusing content.](image3)  [2] A recent Pew Research Center  analysis  of congressional  Facebook pages found that the  “anger” emoticon is now the  most common reaction to posts  by members of Congress. And  although this survey did not ask  about the specific types of  content that might make people  angry, it does find a modest  correlation between the  frequency with which users see  content that makes them angry  and their overall political  affiliation. Some   $31\%$   of  conservative Republicans say  they frequently feel angry due  to things they see on social  media (compared with  $19\%$   of  moderate or liberal  Republicans), as do   $27\%$   of  liberal Democrats (compared  with  $19\%$   of moderate or  conservative Democrats). These findings indicate that users see two types of content especially  frequently: posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (  $58\%$   of users say they see this type of  content frequently) and people making accusations or starting arguments without waiting until  they have all the facts   $(59\%$   see this frequently). ![The image is a bar chart that displays how frequently certain types of posts occur, based on survey responses. ](image5) [12] Previous  surveys by the Center   have found that men are  slightly more likely than women  to encounter any sort of  harassing or abusive behavior  online.
