BERT's performance on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT) was initially impressive, reaching  $77\%$ accuracy, only slightly lower than the average untrained human baseline [1].  ![This table likely benchmarks the performance of AI models on a specific task, comparing them against human baselines.](image1)  Further analysis revealed that this high performance was primarily due to BERT exploiting spurious statistical cues in the dataset [1].  To address this, an adversarial dataset was created by negating the claim and inverting the label for each data point [3]. This mirroring of statistical cues over both labels aimed to provide a more robust evaluation of argument comprehension [3]. 

The adversarial dataset significantly impacted BERT's performance.  When trained and evaluated on this new dataset, BERT's peak accuracy dropped to $53\%$, effectively random performance [5]. ![The table presents test performance metrics (Mean, Median, and Max) for different models and configurations.](image5)  This indicates that BERT's initial success was not due to genuine argument comprehension but rather overfitting to irrelevant cues in the original dataset [5, 6]. 

While the question focuses on BERT, it's worth noting that other models, like BoV and BiLSTM, were also evaluated on the adversarial dataset.  ![The table presents a comparison of the performance metrics for different BERT models, namely "BERT", "BERT (W)", "BERT (R, W)", and "BERT (C, W)", based on their test performance.](image6) These models also experienced a performance drop, indicating that the adversarial dataset successfully removed the spurious cues that were misleadingly inflating performance [12]. 

The adversarial transformation significantly reduced BERT's performance, bringing it down to the level of other models and demonstrating that its initial success was due to exploiting spurious cues rather than actual argument comprehension.

The MultiWOZ dataset [6] encompasses a rich distribution of data across various domains, including restaurant, hotel, attraction, taxi, and train.  ![{The table presents a breakdown of different "Slots" and data distribution for five categories: Hotel, Train, Attraction, Restaurant, and Taxi.}](image1) This dataset is particularly noteworthy due to its large scale, with 30 (domain, slot) pairs and over 4,500 possible values [1, 6], as opposed to older datasets with significantly fewer slots [10]. The dataset is structured to include details such as price range, area, name, and specific attributes like food type for restaurants or parking availability for hotels [1].  The distribution of data across these slots is not uniform, with some slots like "restaurant-name" exhibiting higher error rates in multi-domain training, potentially due to the vast number of possible values [7]. ![{The image is a bar chart showing the error rates of different slots on a test set from multi-domain training, specifically in areas like restaurant, attraction, hotel, taxi, and train domains.}](image2) This non-uniform distribution poses a challenge for models to learn effectively, especially for zero-shot learning where the model needs to generalize to unseen slots [4].  ![{The image contains two bar charts, labeled as Figure 5, showing zero-shot dialogue state tracking (DST) error analysis in two domains: Hotel (a) and Restaurant (b).}](image6) Understanding these distributions is crucial for building effective dialogue state tracking models that can handle the complexity of multi-domain conversations. In conclusion, the MultiWOZ dataset exhibits an uneven distribution of data across various slots and domains, presenting challenges for model training and zero-shot learning.

The "Hard-to-Contrast" querying strategy consistently outperforms other strategies in terms of AUC across different numbers of labeled images, especially in the early cycles of active learning. ![The image consists of ten graphs that compare different methods in terms of Area Under the Curve (AUC) percentage with varying numbers of labeled images.](image5) This superior performance is particularly noticeable when training from scratch, highlighting the importance of initial query selection in active learning. [5] 

The "Hard-to-Contrast" strategy's effectiveness stems from its ability to select data points that are diverse and representative of the underlying data distribution. As seen in various dataset maps, "Hard-to-Contrast" data points occupy areas of medium confidence and higher variability, capturing a wider range of data patterns. ![This image illustrates different querying strategies based on Dataset Maps for the CIFAR-10-LT dataset.](image7) ![This image appears to display an analysis of two medical imaging datasets, PathMNIST and OrganAMNIST, focusing on an active querying approach using Dataset Maps to select data for training machine learning models.](image4) ![This image presents an analysis of a dataset related to blood cells, as indicated by the visual content and the caption text.](image8) This approach helps to overcome the limitations of strategies that rely on ground truth labels or focus solely on easy-to-learn examples, which may result in biased or less informative queries. [8]

Furthermore, the strong correlation observed between the performance in the initial and final cycles of active learning underscores the significance of selecting informative data points early on. [1, 2, 4, 12] ![The table presents performance comparisons across different datasets and methods.](image1) The "Hard-to-Contrast" strategy's ability to achieve high AUC values even with a limited number of labeled images makes it a practical and effective solution for the "cold start" problem in active learning. [9, 11]

In conclusion, the "Hard-to-Contrast" querying strategy consistently achieves higher AUC values across different datasets and numbers of labeled images, demonstrating its effectiveness for initial query selection in active learning, especially for mitigating the "cold start" problem.

The QACheck system, as shown in ![The image is a flowchart illustrating the architecture of the QAC HECK system.](image3), is made up of five key modules: a claim verifier, a question generator, a question-answering module, a QA validator, and a reasoner [3]. Several modules in QACheck utilize large language models (LLMs) like InstructGPT for their functionality [10].  For instance, the claim verifier, a central component of the system, uses InstructGPT and its in-context learning abilities to determine if there's enough information to verify a claim [7].  ![The image contains text related to verifying a claim. It includes highlighted terms such as "CLAIM," "CONTEXT," and "NEW QA PAIR," and asks whether the QA pair provides additional knowledge useful for verifying the claim.](image4) shows an example of how the claim verifier might assess a new question-answer pair in the context of the claim. The question generator, similar to the claim verifier, also leverages InstructGPT for generating relevant questions [2].  ![The image contains text that discusses a process of evaluating a claim. It includes three main sections:

1. "Claim = CLAIM" - indicates that a specific claim is being evaluated, although no concrete claim is provided in the image.

2. "We already know the following: CONTEXT" - suggests that there is some pre-existing context or information related to the claim, which will be considered in the evaluation, but the actual context is not shown in the image.

3. "Can we know whether the claim is true or false now? Yes or no?" - poses a question about the ability to determine the truthfulness of the claim given the context, asking for a binary answer (yes or no).](image6) provides an illustration of how this process might work.  The system also offers alternative implementations for the question-answering module, including a GPT-based reciter-reader model [5]. ![The image depicts three different implementations of a Question Answering (QA) module in a system referred to as QAC HECK.](image2) illustrates these different approaches. Therefore, at least three modules in the QACheck system are implemented with LLMs.

The news encoder has two sub-modules: a title encoder and a topic encoder [1]. The title encoder learns news representations from titles [4] and the topic encoder learns news representations from the topics and subtopics of the news articles [9].  ![The image illustrates a conceptual framework for a news encoder](image5) The final news encoding is formed by combining the encoded subtopic, topic, and title vectors [5]. 

The two sub-modules within the news encoder are the title encoder and the topic encoder.

The two methods, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, are designed to fuse long- and short-term user representations for news recommendation [11]. LSTUR-ini initializes the hidden state of the GRU network in the short-term user representation model with the long-term user representation [3]. In contrast, LSTUR-con concatenates the long-term user representation with the short-term user representation as the final user representation [3]. ![The image depicts two frameworks of the "LSTUR" (Long- and Short-term User Representation) approach for personalized news recommendation systems. It compares two architectures, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, used for processing user click history and candidate news to generate personalized news recommendations.](image3)  As the mask probability *p*, which controls the random masking of long-term user representation during training [4], increases from 0.0 to 0.9, the AUC performance of both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con initially improves [7]. ![The image consists of two line charts comparing the influence of mask probability \( p \) on the performance of two approaches: LSTUR-ini (on the left) and LSTUR-con (on the right).](image8) This suggests that a moderate  *p*  value can properly balance the learning of long-term and short-term user representations [9]. Overall, LSTUR-ini consistently achieves slightly higher AUC scores compared to LSTUR-con across all mask probability values [8]. The performance difference between the two methods, however, is not substantial. ![The table compares the performance of various methods using four different evaluation metrics: AUC (Area Under the Curve), MRR (Mean Reciprocal Rank), nDCG@5 (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain at 5), and nDCG@10 (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain at 10). Each method has a corresponding value for each metric, expressed as a mean ± standard deviation.](image1) LSTUR-ini shows slightly better performance than LSTUR-con in terms of AUC as the mask probability increases.

CodeBERT utilizes a hybrid objective function, incorporating masked language modeling and replaced token detection, to leverage both bimodal data of NL-PL pairs and unimodal code data [7, 12].  This approach allows CodeBERT to learn general-purpose representations that support various downstream NL-PL applications [7, 12].  CodeBERT consistently outperforms RoBERTa and models pre-trained with code only on tasks such as code-to-documentation generation [2, 3, 5].  ![This table compares different models based on their BLEU scores.](image1)  In fact, CodeBERT (MLM+RTD) achieves state-of-the-art performance with a BLEU score of 22.36, surpassing RoBERTa by 2.55 points [6].  This superior performance is evident across different programming languages, demonstrating CodeBERT's ability to generalize to unseen languages [6]. ![This table presents performance metrics of different models across various programming languages including Ruby, JavaScript, Go, Python, Java, and PHP.](image7) Specifically, the CodeBERT (MLM+RTD, init=R) configuration consistently achieves the highest performance scores across most languages, as evidenced by the highlighted results in the table. CodeBERT (MLM+RTD, init=R) shows the best overall performance across programming languages.

The provided text quotes describe a study on incorporating personality traits into recommendation systems using the OCEAN model [2, 4]. The study focuses on three methods [9]: NCF+Most Salient Personality [11], NCF+Soft-labeled Personality [10], and NCF+Hard-coded Personality [8]. The Soft-labeled method utilizes a weighted sum of personality vectors, where weights are derived from OCEAN scores [10].  ![The image is a diagram illustrating a model that uses different methods to integrate personality trait scores represented by the OCEAN model, which includes Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism. In this example, a user has an OCEAN score of {30, 70, 50, 30, 20}. The diagram presents three methods for incorporating these scores into the model:

1. **Method 1: Most Salient Personality** - This method selects the personality trait with the highest score (Conscientiousness in this case, with a score of 70) to create a personality embedding vector. This vector is then used along with a user latent vector and item latent vector in a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to generate a score.

2. **Method 2: Soft-labeled Personality** - This method applies a softmax function to the OCEAN scores to generate probabilities, which are then used to weight the personality embedding matrix. This matrix encompasses all five OCEAN traits, and each trait is represented as a vector. The weighted sum of these vectors acts as the personality embedding.

3. **Method 3: Hard-coded Personality** - This method scales the raw OCEAN scores and fixes them as a personality vector {0.3, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2}, which won't change during training as no gradient is applied to it. Like the other methods, this personality vector is combined with other latent vectors in the MLP to produce a score.

The outputs from these methods, serving as personality embeddings, are combined with a user latent vector and an item latent vector in an MLP to generate a final score. Each method represents a different approach to incorporating personality data into a machine learning model.](image2) However, the question cannot be answered from the given information as the provided quotes and images lack details about specific user data, including the user A2GBIFL43U1LKJ and the colors assigned to personality vectors within the model. Therefore, it is not possible to determine the color of the personality vector associated with the highest Receptiviti score for the mentioned user.

Traditional metrics like BLEU [1] and METEOR [5] are simple and fast but may not accurately capture semantic meaning. The image ![The table presents evaluation metrics for machine translation systems across various language pairs.](image1) shows that YiSi-1 achieves the highest Kendall’s Tau (τ) correlation of 0.440 for the lt-en language pair.  YiSi-1 [3] is a more recent metric designed to evaluate semantic similarity. In contrast to the traditional n-gram matching metrics, COMET, a neural MT evaluation metric, utilizes a pretrained encoder to capture contextual information from the hypothesis, source, and reference texts [1]. The architecture of COMET is illustrated in this image: ![The image is a neural network architecture diagram, showcasing the flow of data through various components used for processing input data.](image5). This approach allows COMET to better understand the meaning of the text and provide a more accurate evaluation. 

YiSi-1 has the highest Kendall's Tau (τ) correlation for the lt-en language pair.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from existing benchmarks by focusing on both breadth and depth of knowledge [6].  Previous benchmarks primarily concentrated on everyday knowledge and common sense, with limited image formats ![This image is a dual representation comparing the MMMU benchmark with other benchmarks.](image4).  

In contrast, MMMU covers 30 image formats, including diagrams, tables, charts, and more, and aims to encompass college-level knowledge across a diverse range of disciplines ![The image is a chart displaying the distribution of 11.5K multimodal questions across six broad disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields.](image1).  Furthermore, MMMU requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge, going beyond the basic perception or simple reasoning tasks seen in other benchmarks [6]. 

This expert-level focus is evident in MMMU's composition: 11.5K questions spanning 6 disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields, with varying difficulty levels and a focus on interleaved text-image inputs ![The table presents statistics on a dataset of questions:](image3). This complexity makes MMMU a more challenging and comprehensive tool for evaluating large multimodal models, pushing beyond basic perception towards expert-level reasoning and domain-specific knowledge application [10].  

The demanding nature of MMMU is highlighted by the performance of even advanced models like GPT-4V, which achieved an accuracy of only 55.7% [8]. This underscores the need for continued development in multimodal understanding and reasoning, particularly in handling complex visual input and integrating domain-specific knowledge [12].

In conclusion, MMMU sets itself apart from other benchmarks through its breadth of disciplines and depth of knowledge, making it a more rigorous and insightful tool for evaluating the expert-level capabilities of large multimodal models.

The COMET-RANK metric, when enhanced with reference translations, demonstrates noteworthy improvement across several language pairs, as evidenced by the results presented in `![{The table presents the results of a translation performance metric called COMET-RANK for various language pairs. The values represent scores that likely indicate the quality of translation, with higher values suggesting better performance. The last row shows the difference between the COMET-RANK score without using reference translations and the score using reference translations.}](image2)`. This observation aligns with the findings of [2], which highlight that learnable metrics, designed to optimize correlation with human judgments, have shown promising outcomes in machine translation evaluation. 

The table reveals that while all language pairs experience an uptick in performance, the most substantial gain is observed in the tr-en (Turkish to English) pair, with a delta τ (Δτ) of 0.132. This suggests that the inclusion of reference translations is particularly beneficial when evaluating translations from Turkish to English. Notably, [10] underscores the potential significance of source language input in enhancing the accuracy of prediction models. The study found that incorporating source embeddings, even when the target language wasn't part of the training data, led to notable improvements. This emphasizes the valuable role of source language information in capturing nuances and improving translation quality assessment. 

The inclusion of reference translations positively impacts the COMET-RANK metric's performance, with the most significant improvement observed in the Turkish to English language pair.

The DYGIE (Dynamic Graph-based Information Extraction) model aims to extract entities, relations, and coreferences from text. ![The image is a diagram illustrating the DYGIE (Dynamic Graph-based Information Extraction) model, which is used for extracting entities, relations, and coreferences from text. The process begins with an input document, split into sentences, and each sentence is processed through a Sentence-level BiLSTM to obtain token representations. Span enumeration identifies possible spans of interest within these token representations.](image1)  This model begins by processing the input document sentence by sentence through a sentence-level BiLSTM [1, 9]. This BiLSTM is responsible for generating token representations that capture the contextual information within each sentence [4].  These representations are then used to identify potential entities and relations within the text [1, 11]. The purpose of the sentence-level BiLSTM in the DYGIE model is to generate token representations that capture contextual information within each sentence.

The system that achieved the highest F1 score for entity recognition on the ACE04 dataset is **DYGIE**.

The creation of COMMONSENSEQA, a commonsense question answering dataset based on CONCEPTNET, involves extracting multiple target concepts sharing the same semantic relationship with a source concept. [10]  For instance, crowd workers might formulate a question about "dust in a house" with options like "attic," "yard," or "street."  ![This image illustrates the process of generating questions for Commonsense QA using the ConceptNet knowledge base.](image8)  These questions are then categorized based on the type of commonsense reasoning they require, such as spatial reasoning or cause-and-effect. [4]  Interestingly, while workers weren't explicitly shown the CONCEPTNET relation, their questions often reflected these relationships, indicating the natural inclination to draw upon commonsense knowledge. [6]  The most frequent relation used in formulating questions for the COMMONSENSEQA dataset is "AtLocation." ![The table consists of three columns:

1. **Relation**: Types of semantic relationships, such as "AtLocation," "Causes," "CapableOf," etc.
2. **Formulated question example**: Example questions related to each relation, with multiple-choice answers (A, B, C, D).
3. **%**: The percentage associated with each relation, indicating the frequency or relevance, with numbers like 47.3, 17.3, 9.4, etc.](image1)  The "AtLocation" relation has a frequency of 47.3%.  Which CONCEPTNET relation has the highest frequency in COMMONSENSEQA according to Table 2? **AtLocation**.

[1, 5] introduced the knowledge graph language model (KGLM), a neural language model that leverages an external knowledge graph to generate more factually accurate text, especially for rare entities and specific tokens like numbers and dates. Traditional language models often struggle with this due to their reliance on memorization.  ![The KGLM model outperforms the others in this table, yielding the lowest scores in both PPL and UPP, which implies better performance in terms of these metrics.](image1) shows that KGLM achieves a perplexity of 44.1, significantly lower than other entity-based language models such as ENTITYNLM (85.4) and EntityCopyNet (76.1). This highlights the importance of integrating knowledge graphs for enhanced language modeling. KGLM also excels in generating rare tokens, as evidenced by its substantially lower unknown penalized perplexity (UPP) compared to the other models. [11] The KGLM model has the lowest Perplexity (PPL) at 44.1.

The table in image8 shows that the data augmentation method that yielded the highest F1-score for the BERT model on both English WSJ and English Tweets datasets is **BERT-Tagger+DSC.**  This method achieved an F1 score of 99.38 on English WSJ, a +0.52 improvement over the baseline BERT-Tagger, and 92.58 on English Tweets, a +0.24 improvement over the baseline BERT-Tagger.  ![{This table shows the precision, recall, and F1 score for different BERT models with different data augmentation methods on English WSJ and English Tweets datasets}](image8) The DSC method helps address the data imbalance issue by attaching similar importance to false positives and false negatives [3]. The system architecture of the dialogue system utilizes a hierarchical LSTM neural network to encode a dialogue [12].  Within this architecture, user input in natural language format is first processed by the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder.  ![The image depicts a proposed architecture for an end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system.](image1) This encoder transforms the user input into a continuous vector representation [12].  Specifically, the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder processes the user utterance by mapping the words to an embedding space and then feeding them as step inputs to a bidirectional LSTM [8]. The function of the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder is to encode the user input into a continuous vector representation.

The model first determines the type of mention ($t_t$) following the phrase "published by." Here, it decides on "Relation to Existing Entity". Once the type is decided, the model identifies the parent entity ($p_t$) from a pool of local entities, selecting "Super Mario Land". Given the parent entity, the model chooses a relation ($r_t$), which is "PUBLISHER" for this instance. Using the parent entity and the selected relation, the model identifies the specific entity to render ($e_t$), which is "Nintendo" in this case, from the local knowledge graph. ![The image is an illustration of a process involving a model, likely a Knowledge Graph Language Model (KGLM), generating a token based on the context of a sentence and related knowledge graph information.](image2) The model picks  Super Mario Land  as the parent entity,  Publication Date  as the relation to render, and copies one of the tokens of the date entity as the token (“ 1989 ” in this case). [7] Then the model selects Nintendo  as the entity to render   ($e_t$). [7] The model decides the entity to render through a series of steps including determining the mention type, identifying the parent entity, choosing the relation, and then finally rendering the entity.

The tree traversal method involves a multi-layered approach to retrieving information. [4] This method offers control over the specificity and breadth of the retrieved information by adjusting the depth  $d$ and the number of nodes $k$ selected at each layer. [4] This process is described as selecting the top $k$ nodes from the child nodes of the previously selected set. [2]  This selection is based on the highest cosine similarity scores to the query. [2] This iterative selection process, as illustrated in `![Algorithm for traversing the tree structure.](image2)`, continues for $d$ layers, ultimately producing sets $S_1, S_2, ..., S_d$. [2] 
The pseudocode for this step from the appendix is:

```python
S_layer = [node for node, score in sorted(top_k)[:k].nodes]
```

Perplexity is a common metric used to evaluate dialogue models, though it has limitations, especially in a retrieve and refine context [8]. The lower the perplexity value, the better the model performance.  As shown in the table, using the true label as a retrieval method results in significantly lower perplexity (PPL of 9.2) compared to other methods. ![The table presents a comparison of various retrieval methods used in conjunction with a sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) model, by showing their associated perplexity (PPL) scores.](image7) Using the true label's neighbor also yields a relatively low perplexity of 25.9.  However, it's important to note that using the true label or its neighbor as retrieval methods is not feasible in a real-world setting [12]. These methods serve as sanity checks and upper bounds for performance comparison [10]. The true label method works best because if the retrieval points the model to a different but equally valid response, the model might focus on refining that and get poor perplexity [8].

The true label retrieval method shows the best performance in terms of perplexity.

This system tackles the limitations of previous fact-checking models that lacked transparency in their reasoning or were restricted to single-document validation [8, 9]. The final step is **Label**.

The DS-DST model utilizes a dual-strategy approach to determine matching between candidate values and dialogue context. [5] It leverages a fixed BERT model to process the candidate-value list for each categorical slot, generating value representations. [8]  Meanwhile, a fine-tuned BERT model handles the dialogue context, encoding information from the recent conversation and domain-slot pairs.  ![The image is a schematic representation of the DS-DST model architecture.](image8) For instance, if the dialogue context involves a user seeking an "expensive" hotel, the model would process this context alongside the domain-slot pair "hotel, price range." [1]  The model then calculates the cosine similarity between these representations to determine the most relevant match. [1] The DS-DST model's effectiveness is evident in its performance, significantly outperforming other models like BERT-DST on the MultiWOZ datasets. [10]  ![The table presents a comparison of different models based on their joint accuracy.](image2) This superior performance highlights the model's ability to effectively capture the relationship between candidate values and dialogue context. The model's architecture allows for a nuanced understanding of user requests, as demonstrated in its ability to handle both categorical and non-categorical slots with high accuracy. [6] This is further supported by the model's performance on individual slots, where it consistently achieves high accuracy across various categories. [3] ![The table displays accuracy percentages for various slots across three different models: DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist.](image6)

The DS-DST model determines the matching between candidate values and the dialogue context by calculating the cosine similarity between their respective representations.

Classic MT evaluation metrics rely on assessing the similarity between a machine-generated translation and a human-generated reference translation in the target language [7].  Metrics like BLEU and METEOR are popular for their lightweight and fast computation [7]. However, these metrics, characterized as n-gram matching metrics, often fail to recognize and capture semantic similarity beyond the lexical level [4]. The COMET framework leverages recent breakthroughs in cross-lingual language modeling to generate prediction estimates of human judgments like Direct Assessments (DA), Human-mediated Translation Edit Rate (HTER), and metrics compliant with the Multidimensional Quality Metric (MQM) framework [9].

Answer: COMET-Rank consistently performs the best across the language pairs.

The LOGIC-LM model solves problems by breaking them down into three key stages: Problem Formulation, Symbolic Reasoning, and Result Interpretation [12]. 

![The image is a diagram outlining the structure of the LOGIC-LM model](image5)

Initially, the Problem Formulator module translates the natural language problem into a symbolic representation using in-context learning from LLMs [12]. This module identifies the core entities, facts, and rules within the problem statement [12].  For instance, deductive reasoning problems can be formulated using Logical Programming (LP) as demonstrated by the example, "If the circuit is complete and the circuit has the light bulb then the light bulb is glowing," which translates to `Complete(Circuit, True) ∧ Has(Circuit, LightBulb) → Glowing(LightBulb, True)` in symbolic form [6]. 

![The table presents an overview of different problem types and their corresponding formulations in the context of logic and reasoning](image6)

Following the problem formulation, the Symbolic Reasoner comes into play. This module utilizes different methods like Logic Programming, First-order Logic Prover, and Constraint Optimization to perform logical inference on the symbolically represented problem [5]. Depending on the nature of the problem, a specific solver is selected, such as Pyke for deductive reasoning or Prover9 for First-order Logic [6].  Finally, the Result Interpreter module translates the symbolic answer generated by the Symbolic Reasoner into a human-understandable format, effectively providing a solution to the original problem [12]. 

The LOGIC-LM model solves a problem by using its modules to translate the problem into a symbolic representation, performing logical reasoning, and then interpreting the results to provide a solution.

DS-DST, a dual-strategy dialogue state tracking model, employs a BERT-based question answering framework to manage both categorical and non-categorical slots [5]. 
This approach allows for direct interaction between dialogue context and slot information, as illustrated in `![DS-DST Model Architecture](image2)` which showcases the model's architecture.  The model excels at handling slots like "hotel-type", "attraction-type", "attraction-name", "hotel-internet", and "hotel-parking", as their values often have diverse expressions, making them difficult to extract solely from dialogue context [6]. This is evident in examples like the dialogue focusing on a restaurant and attraction booking, as shown in `![Dialogue Example: Restaurant and Attraction Booking](image1)`.  The accuracy of DS-DST for the hotel-type slot is **47.71%** [11].

CodeBERT is a pre-trained model for programming languages (PL) and natural language (NL) that uses a hybrid objective function, incorporating replaced token detection (RTD) and masked language modeling (MLM) [4]. When pre-trained with both MLM and RTD objectives, CodeBERT achieves a BLEU score of 22.36. This outperforms other models such as RoBERTa, which scores 19.81, and a model pre-trained with code only, which scores 20.65 ![This table compares different models based on their BLEU scores.](image7). CodeBERT's performance is also significantly better than models like MOSES, IR, SUM-NN, and even CodeNN [7]. Notably, CodeBERT's performance with MLM+RTD surpasses that of CodeBERT with just MLM (22.32) or RTD (22.14) objectives, highlighting the benefit of the hybrid approach. While Code2Seq slightly outperforms CodeBERT, this difference might be attributed to Code2Seq's utilization of compositional paths in the abstract syntax tree (AST) [12]. CodeBERT, on the other hand, relies solely on the original code as input. Future research could explore incorporating AST into CodeBERT to potentially boost its performance further [12].  CodeBERT (MLM+RTD) achieves the highest BLEU score of 22.36.

The image describes two information retrieval mechanisms using tree structures: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval. ![The image illustrates two mechanisms for retrieving information using tree structures: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval.](image1) In Tree Traversal Retrieval, the process starts by encoding a query into a vector and traversing the tree from the root, retrieving the top nodes at each level based on cosine similarity to the query vector [1].  The collapsed tree approach, on the other hand, flattens the tree into a single layer, allowing for simultaneous comparison of all nodes [4]. This method retrieves nodes based on cosine similarity until a certain number of tokens are reached [3].  The image highlights the nodes where cosine similarity calculations are performed in both mechanisms. The nodes that appear in more than one cluster in Figure 1 are colored **orange**.

SenseBERT surpasses the performance of other language models on the Word in Context (WiC) task, as shown in Table 2 [3]. Figure 1 in the paper showcases an example of a scientific claim and the reasoning process for verification. The claim is about "A's productivity of 57.5% expressing that it appears in 7.5% more often than expected by random chance." [11] To verify this claim, the reasoning graph in the figure employs three steps. [11] It starts by leveraging background knowledge to link "productivity" with the "Prod." column in the table. [11] Then, commonsense knowledge helps establish 50% as the random chance. [11] Lastly, simple subtraction confirms the 7.5% difference, leading to the conclusion that the claim is valid. ![The image illustrates an example from a dataset called S CI T AB, along with a reasoning graph.](image5)  The figure demonstrates that verifying claims in this dataset often requires multiple reasoning steps, confirming the complex and nuanced nature of scientific fact-checking. [9]  The reasoning depth analysis of the dataset reveals that the claims require an average of 4.76 reasoning steps, with a maximum of 11 steps. [7] This complexity highlights the challenging nature of the dataset, as 86% of the claims need 3 or more reasoning steps for verification. [7] ![The image is a histogram depicting the distribution of reasoning steps in a dataset known as SCI TAB.](image8) The figure requires **3 reasoning steps** to verify the claim.

Answer: Fake news sources and mainstream news sources.

  - **[NA] Precision**: Evaluates the accuracy of [NA] tagging in sentences when compared to the absent knowledge set.

The BiDAF model consistently outperforms FastQA on both the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets. ![The table presents the performance results of different models on two datasets, WIKIHOP and MEDHOP.](image6) This superior performance is potentially attributed to BiDAF's iterative latent interactions, which are believed to be advantageous for tasks involving information spread across multiple documents, as explained in [12]. The importance of these interactions is heightened in multi-hop question answering scenarios where integrating information from various sources is crucial. However, despite outperforming FastQA, both models show significant improvement when provided with a pre-selected set of relevant documents, highlighting a challenge in effectively identifying and utilizing information from a larger pool of documents [8].  FastQA, with its simpler architecture, seems to struggle even further with integrating cross-document information [5]. It's also important to note the impact of answer masking on model performance. While both models generally maintain or improve their performance with masked answers, there's a noticeable difference between WIKIHOP and MEDHOP [10]. This difference stems from the nature of entity representation in the two datasets, where MEDHOP utilizes normalized identifiers for drug mentions, leading to a performance drop under masking. In contrast, WIKIHOP, with its open-domain setting and masked single-token expressions, sees an improvement in candidate span selection. Although both models outperform other baselines, their performance still falls short of human performance, indicating room for further development, particularly in intelligent document selection before applying the RC model [8].  BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA on both WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets.

[9] This suggests that ProgramFC's approach of decomposing complex claims into simpler steps with a program contributes to its higher accuracy in fact-checking, especially for tasks requiring complex reasoning. [5] ProgramFC (N=5) outperforms other models on the HOVER (4-hop) dataset in both Gold and Open settings.

This approach is particularly beneficial for "hard" samples, where SLMs might struggle [10].  ![The image contains three line graphs comparing the relationship between confidence scores and micro-F1 performance, with and without LLM reranking using RoBERTa-large as a filter and Instruct GPT as a reranker. The provided datasets, D1 through D4, are derived from reviews from restaurants and electronic devices. [2] The datasets are categorized into positive, negative, and neutral classes. [2] ![The table shows the number of positive, negative, and neutral reviews in the training and test sets for datasets D1-D4.](image1)  A significant observation is the variation in the distribution of neutral examples across these datasets. Dataset D1 (Restaurant14) has a substantial number of neutral examples in both training and test sets. This is followed by D2 (Laptop14). However, D3 (Restaurant15) and D4 (Restaurant16) exhibit a significantly smaller number of neutral examples. [10] The scarcity of neutral examples in the training sets of D3 and D4 makes it challenging for classifiers to learn neutral-related features effectively. [10]

The impact of this uneven distribution is evident in the performance of the models, particularly in terms of Macro-F1 scores, which are sensitive to class imbalance. [5] D3 and D4, with fewer neutral examples, show lower Macro-F1 scores compared to D1. [5] Introducing document-level knowledge through methods like PRET and MULT, which leverage information from datasets with more balanced distributions, helps improve performance, especially on datasets like D3 and D4. [1, 8]  ![The graph depicts the accuracy and Macro-F1 scores for datasets D1-D4 as the percentage of document-level training examples increases.](image2) This improvement is likely because the added document-level data helps to compensate for the lack of neutral examples in the aspect-level datasets. [12]

In conclusion, the distribution of neutral examples varies significantly across datasets D1 to D4, with D3 and D4 having considerably fewer neutral examples, leading to challenges in model training and performance, particularly in terms of Macro-F1 scores.

In Named Entity Recognition (NER), the model benefits from both word-level and character-level information. Word embeddings, like those from fastText [9] or GloVe [9], capture the semantic meaning of a word as a whole. However, relying solely on word embeddings can be problematic, especially when dealing with languages that have complex morphology or when encountering words not present in the pre-trained embeddings [11]. 

This is where character-level embeddings come in. By processing words at the character level, the model can infer meaning from the internal structure of the word, which is helpful for understanding out-of-vocabulary words or languages with rich morphology. This approach is illustrated in the architecture of a self-attentive Bi-LSTM-CRF model ![The image depicts the architecture of a Self-attentive Bi-LSTM-CRF model used for Named Entity Recognition (NER). The model takes in word and character embeddings and uses Bi-LSTM, self-attention, and a CRF layer to predict named entities.](image3) where a character-level Bi-LSTM is used to create character embeddings.

Furthermore, as indicated in [7], utilizing character-level information in conjunction with word embeddings allows the model to leverage the original character sequences of the target language, which contributes to increased tagging accuracy.

The model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs to capture both the semantic meaning of words and the internal structure of words, which is particularly useful for handling out-of-vocabulary words and languages with complex morphology.

In the context of object detection datasets, images often contain multiple objects of varying sizes [8]. To address this, a two-step pre-processing approach is employed, as illustrated in the diagram. ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image8)  First, based on proposal bounding box coordinates, regions of interest within the image are cropped and resized to a fixed proportion [8]. Cropping ensures that the model focuses on individual objects rather than the entire image. Subsequently, a blurring technique is applied to the non-target areas surrounding the objects of interest [8]. This blurring strategy helps to guide the model's attention towards the relevant objects, similar to how Gaussian blurring can improve classification accuracy by maintaining context while emphasizing the foreground object [7]. This pre-processing pipeline enhances the system's ability to perform zero-shot object recognition by providing focused and contextually relevant image embeddings for the retrieval and ranking process.

In short, the pre-processing step, consisting of cropping and blurring, enhances the system's zero-shot recognition capabilities by creating focused and contextually relevant image embeddings.

The QACheck model, as shown in ![The table displays the performance of different models on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets, comparing their accuracy on tasks with varying reasoning depths.](image7), achieves a macro-F1 score of 54.67 on HOVER three-hop claims. In comparison, InstructGPT with direct prompting scores 51.75, while InstructGPT with CoT prompting reaches 53.66.  Codex scores 53.42, FLAN-T5 scores 52.11, and ProgramFC scores 54.18 on the same 3-hop HOVER dataset [6]. The QACheck system utilizes a question-guided reasoning approach to decompose complex claims into simpler steps for more accurate reasoning [5], as illustrated in ![The flowchart describes the architecture of QACheck, a system that verifies claims through a series of question-answering and validation steps.](image6).  This approach proves beneficial, particularly for claims demanding higher reasoning depth, where QACheck demonstrates greater improvement over end-to-end models [6]. QACheck outperforms FLAN-T5, which, despite being a Seq2Seq model pretrained on numerous tasks and capable of generating answers and evidence directly from the question [1], might struggle with claims outside the scope of its training data. The model's performance surpasses InstructGPT with direct prompting and is on par with models like ProgramFC that employ claim decomposition strategies [6]. Users can further tailor the QA component within QACheck by choosing from various implementations, including the retriever-reader model, FLAN-T5, or the GPT3-based reciter-reader model, as depicted in ![The image shows three different QA implementations: Retriever-Reader, FLAN-T5, and GPT Reciter-Reader, each demonstrating a distinct approach to processing questions and generating answers.](image2) [10].  This adaptability enhances its flexibility in handling complex claims.  The QACheck model performs similarly to other models like Codex and ProgramFC in handling 3-hop questions on the HOVER dataset.

GCAN, a graph-aware co-attention network designed for fake news detection, utilizes various components to achieve high accuracy [1]. To understand the contribution of each component, an ablation analysis was conducted by removing one component at a time [6]. Removing both source tweet embeddings and dual co-attention, represented as "-S-A", resulted in a significant accuracy drop [11]. ![The image shows a bar graph comparing the accuracy of different GCAN sub-models on Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets.](image1) This highlights the importance of source tweets in providing fundamental clues for detection [11]. 

The "-S-A" configuration consistently yielded the lowest accuracy on the Twitter15 dataset. The source tweet and dual co-attention mechanism are crucial for GCAN's performance, signifying their role in effective fake news detection. Removing both leads to the least accurate GCAN sub-model. The sub-model with both source tweet embeddings and dual co-attention removed ("-S-A") resulted in the lowest accuracy for Twitter15.

While evaluating the performance of different dialogue generation models, human evaluation is critical. [1]  For instance, perplexity, a commonly used metric, might not accurately reflect the quality of responses in dialogue systems.  ![The table presents a comparison of various retrieval methods used in conjunction with a sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) model, by showing their associated perplexity (PPL) scores.](image1) This is because there can be multiple valid responses in a dialogue, and a model might achieve low perplexity by focusing on refining a retrieved response that differs significantly from the true response but is still valid. [1] Besides, analyzing word statistics, such as word count, character count, and the use of rare words, can offer insights into the salience of a generation model. [4] ![The table shows a comparison of different methods based on four metrics: Word Count (cnt), Character Count (cnt), Rare Word Percentage for words appearing less than 100 times, and Rare Word Percentage for words appearing less than 1,000 times.](image4) It's been observed that Seq2Seq models tend to produce shorter sentences with more common words compared to human responses. [4]  To address these limitations, human evaluation was conducted, focusing on engagingness, consistency, fluency, and persona usage. [5] ![The table compares different methods based on four metrics: Engagingness, Fluency, Consistency, and Persona. Each metric includes a mean value with a standard deviation in parentheses.](image5) The results show that the RetNRef ++ model, which leverages retrieval and refinement techniques, exhibits promising performance in terms of engagingness. [6]  It outperforms other models, including the Memory Network and Seq2Seq, and demonstrates an ability to generate more engaging and human-like conversations. [6, 11]

**RetrieveNRefine++** scored the highest in the Engagingness metric.

The accuracy on  $N^{D}$  is the criterion to reflect the performance of the discriminator [6]. In the early epochs, the generated samples from the generator increases the accuracy. However, as the training epoch increases, this accuracy gradually decreases, which means the discriminator becomes weaker [6]. ![The image is a line graph displaying the performance change of a discriminator on $N^{D}$ during the training process over multiple epochs.](image6) Note that there is a critical point of the decline of accuracy for each presented relation types [6].  This critical point is yielded when the generator has already been robust enough [6]. The accuracy of the discriminator for the relation type /people/person/place_lived shows a critical point of decline around epoch 20.

Distant supervision (DS) is a method used in relation extraction, but it can introduce noise in the labeled sentences [4]. DSGAN uses an adversarial learning process with a generator and a discriminator to identify and utilize true positive samples from the noisy dataset [4, 10].  The generator in DSGAN is responsible for generating true positive samples, aiming to make the discriminator classify these samples as negative [2]. ![The image is a flowchart illustrating a machine learning process involving a generator and a discriminator.](image4) The discriminator, on the other hand, is trained to differentiate between positive and negative samples [2].  As the training progresses, the generator improves its ability to produce accurate true positive samples, gradually decreasing the discriminator's performance [8].  This adversarial process continues until the discriminator's accuracy on the negative dataset ($N^{D}$) no longer decreases significantly, indicating the generator's success in collapsing the discriminator [8]. ![The image is a line graph displaying the performance change of a discriminator on $N^{D}$ during the training process over multiple epochs.](image1) This training process results in a robust generator that can effectively distinguish true positive samples from the noisy DS data [8].

 The effectiveness of the DSGAN approach is evaluated by applying the generator to filter the noisy DS dataset before relation extraction [6]. The performance improvement is observed by comparing the results of state-of-the-art models trained on both the original noisy dataset and the filtered dataset [6]. ![The image is a graph displaying aggregate Precision-Recall (PR) curves for models based on PCNN (Piecewise Convolutional Neural Network).](image3) The AUC (Area Under the Curve) values of the PR (Precision-Recall) curves are used to quantify the performance difference, with a larger AUC value indicating better performance [9]. The results demonstrate that the models trained on the filtered dataset, after applying the DSGAN generator, consistently achieve higher AUC values compared to those trained on the original noisy dataset [9]. ![The table presents a comparison of model performance with and without the addition of DSGAN across different models.](image8) The improvement in AUC values across different models highlights the effectiveness of DSGAN in enhancing the performance of distant supervision relation extraction by providing a cleaner dataset [9].

PCNN+ONE showed the largest improvement in AUC value after the addition of DSGAN.

The evolution of tracing diachronic semantic shifts from 2010 to 2017 can be visualized as a timeline of key milestones. 
![The image is a timeline chart illustrating key milestones in the field of distributional models aimed at tracing diachronic semantic shifts from 2010 to 2017.](image1) 
These milestones mark significant advancements in methodologies and datasets.  Starting with the introduction of the "Time tensor with Random Indexing" in 2010 [1], the field progressed to utilizing large corpora like the "Google Ngrams corpus" in 2011 [12]. Further advancements included "Word epoch disambiguation" in 2012 [3], followed by the use of "Prediction-based models" in 2013 [10]. The year 2014 marked a turning point with the adoption of "Word embeddings", such as "word2vec" [10], for analyzing semantic shifts. By 2015, researchers were exploring techniques for "Models alignment" [5]. The subsequent years saw the use of diverse corpora like the "NYT corpus" and "COHA corpus" [8] in 2016, and the exploration of "Laws of semantic change" and other insights in 2017 [2].  The key milestones from 2010 to 2017 in tracing diachronic semantic shifts involved advancements in methodologies and the use of large corpora.

The researchers used their S PECTER model for several classification tasks, including one with the MeSH dataset [2].  SPECTER uses a transformer model, initialized with SciBERT, and is trained by minimizing a triplet loss function that encourages related papers to be closer together in the embedding space than unrelated papers  ![{The image provides an overview of the SPECTER model, which is used for document embedding, specifically for scientific paper analysis. It utilizes a transformer model that is initialized with SciBERT, which is a BERT-based model pre-trained on scientific text data. The image outlines the inputs to the transformer which include a query paper (denoted as \(P^Q\)), a related paper (denoted as \(P^+\)), and an unrelated paper (denoted as \(P^-\)). 

The outputs are embeddings of these papers, which are used to compute a triplet loss. The formula for triplet loss given in the image is:
\[ \text{Triplet loss} = \max \left( d(P^Q, P^+) - d(P^Q, P^-) + m, 0 \right) \]
where \(d\) represents a distance measure between the embeddings, and \(m\) is a margin parameter used in the triplet loss calculation. The goal is to ensure that the distance between the query and the related paper is smaller than the distance between the query and the unrelated paper by at least the margin \(m\).}](image1).   The results of the classification tasks, shown in a table, compare SPECTER to fine-tuned versions of SciBERT. ProgramFC consistently outperforms one-step retrieval in terms of retrieval recall across different tasks. [11] This is evident in the improved retrieval recall observed in HOVER (2-hop, 3-hop, 4-hop) and FEVEROUS-S tasks. ![The image is a bar chart comparing retrieval recall between one-step retrieval and ProgramFC across different tasks, showing that ProgramFC consistently achieves higher recall.](image2) The most significant improvement is observed in HOVER 4-hop, where ProgramFC achieves a 37.1% improvement over one-step retrieval. This suggests that decomposing a complex claim into simpler steps using a program can facilitate more accurate reasoning, especially when the required reasoning is complex. [7] The iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program in ProgramFC contributes to better retrieval recall because some information may not be present in the original claim but is revealed during the reasoning process. [11] ProgramFC achieves this by combining the retrieved paragraphs of all steps and considering the top-10 results. [11]  ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval in terms of retrieval recall across all datasets.

Data imbalance is a common issue in a variety of NLP tasks such as tagging and machine reading comprehension [10].  For the Named Entity Recognition (NER) task, most tokens are backgrounds with tagging class  $O$  [10]. Specifically, the number of tokens with tagging class $O$ is 5 times as many as those with entity labels for the CoNLL03 dataset and 8 times for the OntoNotes5.0 dataset [10]. ![The table contains information about various tasks and their datasets.](image4) The negative-positive ratio is 169 for the QUOREF dataset [4].  Data- imbalanced issue is more severe for MRC tasks with the value of negative-positive ratio being 50-200 [10].  This is due to the reason that the task of MRC is usually formalized as predicting the starting and ending indexes conditioned on the query and the context, and given a chunk of text of an arbitrary length, only two tokens are positive (or of interest) with all the rest being background [10]. The ratio of negative to positive instances for the QUOREF dataset is 169, which is higher than other datasets.

![{This image illustrates different querying strategies based on Dataset Maps for the CIFAR-10-LT dataset.}](image1)
 In active learning, the selection of data points for labeling is crucial, particularly in the context of the "cold start" problem where labeled data is scarce. [10] utilizes Dataset Maps, which are scatter plots visualizing data points based on their confidence and variability, to guide data selection. Traditionally, these maps rely on ground truth labels to categorize data points into "easy-to-learn" and "hard-to-learn" categories. [10] However, obtaining ground truth labels for the entire dataset is impractical, especially in active learning scenarios.
![{The image appears to display an analysis of two medical imaging datasets, PathMNIST and OrganAMNIST, focusing on an active querying approach using Dataset Maps to select data for training machine learning models.}](image6)
 To address this limitation, [10] proposes using pseudo-labels derived from methods like $K$-means clustering. This approach generates a "Data Map by pseudo-labels," where data points are categorized as "easy-to-contrast" or "hard-to-contrast" based on their relative difficulty in being distinguished from other data points within the feature space. [8] This method proves particularly advantageous in the absence of extensive ground truth labels, offering a practical solution for the cold start problem. 
The map by pseudo-labels has a larger confidence variance.

The table is structured into multiple turns, and each turn has several components:
- **User**: This column contains the user's input or request.
- **Ground Truths**: This represents the correct set of key-value pairs related to the user's request, such as train departure, train arrival, hotel stars, etc.
- **DS-Span**: This column lists the data spans identified from the user's input, representing specific pieces of information extracted for processing.
- **DS-DST**: This column shows the dialogue state tracking information, which maintains the accumulated values and slots inferred throughout the conversation.](image7) ![The table presents a dialogue between a user and a system, focusing on planning a trip to a restaurant and a nearby attraction. The dialogue is divided into turns, each containing user inputs, system responses, and associated ground truths for dialogue state tracking.

Conversely, DS-Picklist leverages access to a full ontology, allowing it to accurately predict slot values even when not explicitly mentioned in the dialogue. WinoMT is a challenge set created by concatenating the Winogender and WinoBias coreference test sets to evaluate gender bias in MT [4, 7]. The Winogender dataset contains an equal number of male, female, and neutral instances (240 each), resulting in a total of 720 instances. On the other hand, WinoBias has a more significant number of instances, with 1582 male and 1586 female instances, totaling 3168 instances. As a result of combining these two datasets, WinoMT comprises 1826 male, 1822 female, and 240 neutral instances, adding up to 3888 instances in total ![This table presents a breakdown of data across three categories (Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT) by gender classification (Male, Female, Neutral).](image3). 

Overall, WinoMT has a balanced distribution of male and female instances and includes neutral instances from Winogender [3]. Winogender has an equal distribution of male, female, and neutral instances, while WinoBias primarily consists of male and female instances. The WinoMT dataset combines both datasets, resulting in a larger dataset with a balanced distribution of male and female instances and a smaller proportion of neutral instances. 

The distribution of gendered instances in the WinoMT dataset is balanced, with a nearly equal number of male and female instances, while Winogender and WinoBias have different distributions.

The BERT model achieves a peak performance of 77% accuracy on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task, just three points below the average untrained human baseline [1, 6].  However, this high performance is likely due to the model exploiting spurious statistical cues in the dataset rather than demonstrating true argument comprehension [1, 5, 10]. This is evident when the model is tested on an adversarial dataset designed to eliminate these cues [12]. In this case, BERT's performance drops to approximately random chance, with a mean and median accuracy of 50% [9]. 

![The table presents test performance metrics (Mean, Median, and Max) for different models and configurations.](image4)

For example, when tested on warrants alone (W), BERT achieves a maximum accuracy of 71%. Adding cues over reasons (R, W) and claims (C, W) only accounts for the remaining six percentage points to reach its peak performance [5]. This suggests that BERT heavily relies on these superficial cues rather than understanding the underlying arguments. 

![The table presents a comparison of the performance metrics for different BERT models, namely "BERT", "BERT (W)", "BERT (R, W)", and "BERT (C, W)", based on their test performance.](image5)

This finding is further supported by the fact that other models, such as BoV and BiLSTM, exhibit similar patterns of performance degradation on the adversarial dataset [9]. Additionally, BERT's performance becomes much closer to random chance when trained and evaluated on the adversarial dataset, with a peak accuracy of 53% [9]. 

In conclusion, BERT's test performance varies significantly across different configurations, with its high performance on the original dataset primarily attributed to exploiting spurious cues rather than true argument comprehension.

The baseline performance of PaLM-2L and GPT-4 on the MuSiQue dataset is low, at 35.5% and 38.5% respectively [4]. This is because MuSiQue is a challenging multi-hop reasoning benchmark [4]. In contrast, StrategyQA has stronger baseline performance, with PaLM-2L achieving 82.8% and GPT-4 achieving 78.3% [4]. This difference in baseline performance is likely due to StrategyQA being a binary classification task [4]. While prompting techniques like CoT and TDB show slight improvements on MuSiQue, they don't significantly impact StrategyQA's performance due to its already high baseline [4]. Applying RAG does improve performance on both datasets, but the most significant improvement is seen when using Step-Back Prompting with RAG [4]. This combination results in 42.8% accuracy on MuSiQue and 86.4% on StrategyQA, outperforming all other methods, including GPT-4 [4]. ![The table compares performance of different methods on MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets.](image6) This suggests that the combination of Step-Back prompting, which helps in abstraction [2], and RAG, which retrieves relevant information [1], is particularly effective for tasks that require multi-hop reasoning and knowledge integration, leading to substantial performance gains.

The combination of Step-Back prompting with RAG significantly improves performance on MuSiQue and StrategyQA compared to other prompting methods.

STEP-BACK PROMPTING  is a simple prompting technique that enables LLMs to derive high-level concepts and first principles from instances containing specific details [11]. 
The method significantly improves the model's ability to follow a correct reasoning path toward a solution [11].  
For example, when evaluated on the MMLU benchmark, which requires deeper reasoning and understanding of physics and chemistry principles [2], PaLM-2L + Step-Back achieved state-of-the-art performance, surpassing GPT-4 [12].

As shown in the table, PaLM-2L + Step-Back achieved  73.2% in MMLU Physics. 
PaLM-2L + Step-Back also exhibits robust performance across other tasks, such as TimeQA and MuSiQue, demonstrating its efficacy in tackling complex reasoning-intensive tasks [10].

PaLM-2L + Step-Back achieved a score of 73.2% in MMLU Physics.

RAPTOR employs two querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree [1]. The tree traversal method goes through the tree layer by layer, selecting the most relevant nodes at each level [9, 10, 11]. In contrast, the collapsed tree method evaluates all nodes in the tree at the same time to locate the most relevant ones [4, 9]!["This image illustrates Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval."](image3) 

A study was conducted to compare the performance of these two methods on the QASPER dataset [6]. The results indicate that the collapsed tree method consistently outperforms tree traversal [6]. !["This graph illustrates the F1 score of Collapsed Tree and Tree Traversal across different context lengths."](image8) This superior performance is attributed to the collapsed tree method's flexibility in retrieving information at the appropriate level of detail [6]. The collapsed tree method, using 2000 tokens, demonstrated the best results in this dataset [6]. Ultimately, because of its flexibility and strong performance, the collapsed tree approach is the chosen querying method [5].

The collapsed tree method achieves a higher F1 score compared to the tree traversal method, especially with a context length of 2000 tokens.

Logic-LM leverages the reasoning power of symbolic solvers to enhance the logical problem-solving abilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) [6].  As shown in  ![Performance comparison of different models on various datasets.](image2), Logic-LM consistently outperforms both standard LLMs and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting across all five datasets: PrOntoQA, ProofWriter, FOLIO, LogicalDeduction, and AR-LSAT. This superior performance is particularly noticeable with GPT-3.5 as the base LLM, where Logic-LM achieves an average improvement of 39.2% over the standard LLM approach [8]. This underscores the efficacy of integrating symbolic solvers with LLMs for tackling logical reasoning tasks.  ![Accuracy of different models with increasing reasoning depth.](image1) further demonstrates that Logic-LM exhibits greater resilience to increasing problem complexity compared to standard LLMs and CoT.  While the performance of the baseline models deteriorates significantly with increasing reasoning depth, Logic-LM maintains a more stable accuracy rate. This suggests that offloading the reasoning process to dedicated symbolic solvers effectively mitigates the performance degradation commonly observed in purely language-based reasoning methods. Logic-LM (without self-refinement) outperforms the two baseline models in **all five datasets** when using GPT-4 as the base language model.

Fact-checking systems often lack transparency in their decision-making [7]. To address this, Question-guided Multi-hop Fact-Checking (QAC HECK) was proposed, which guides the model’s reasoning process by asking a series of questions critical for verifying a claim [7]. One example of this reasoning process is verifying the claim “Sunlight can reach the deepest part of the Black Sea” [6].  First, the question “What is the greatest depth of the Black Sea?” is raised. After gathering relevant information from the Web, the answer to this question is 2,212 meters. ![The image illustrates a process for fact-checking the claim: "Sunlight can travel to the deepest part of the Black Sea."](image2) Next, the question “How far can sunlight penetrate water?” is raised [1].  After gathering information from the web, we know the answer is that sunlight does not penetrate water below 1,000 meters [1]. Thus, because 2,212 meters is greater than 1,000 meters, the claim is false [1].  ![The image illustrates a process for fact-checking the claim: "Sunlight can travel to the deepest part of the Black Sea."](image2)  QAC HECK  provides a comprehensive report detailing its reasoning process, guided by a sequence of (question, answer) pairs, as well as the source of evidence supporting each question [7]. ![The image shows a user interface of a fact-checking demo called "QACheck: Question-Guided Multi-hop Fact-Checking Demo."](image1)  The system has been evaluated on its performance in verifying multi-hop claims and achieves a macro-F1 score of 55.67, 54.67, and 52.35 on HOVER two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively, and a 59.47 F1 score on FEVEROUS [5]. ![The table presents the performance of different AI models on two datasets: HOVER and FEVEROUS.](image6)  These scores are better than directly using Instruct GP T, Codex, or FLAN-T5 and are on par with systems that apply claim decomposition strategies [5]. The example figure of question-guided reasoning mentions two numbers with blue color: **2,212 and 1,000**.

The table highlights that the Distant Supervision configuration achieves the highest macro F1-score. ![The table presents the performance of different configurations of models on two datasets, Snopes and PolitiFact.](image4)  The Distant Supervision configuration achieved the highest macro F1-score.

Welcome to Bergen’s oldest Latin School, dating from 1706. Experience a 13th-century royal banqueting hall, the first of its kind to be built in stone, at Haakon’s Hall [6]. The museums in Bergen associated with historical or cultural heritage are Bergen's oldest Latin School, Osterøy Museum, Old Bergen Museum, Bryggens Museum, and Haakon’s Hall.

The recommended control settings for the refrigerator and freezer are essential for optimal food storage [4].  When both the refrigerator and freezer compartments are too warm, it could be due to several factors, such as frequent door openings, a large amount of food recently added, or extreme room temperatures [5]. ![This table shows recommended control settings for different temperature conditions in the refrigerator and freezer](image5).  For optimal cooling, it's important to give the refrigerator ample time to cool down completely after plugging it in, which may take several hours [8]. The refrigerator control adjustments range from 1 (warmest) to 5 (coldest), and the freezer control adjustments range from A (warmest) to C (coldest) [8].  ![This image shows the control panel for a refrigerator and a freezer.](image3). You should set the Refrigerator Control to 4 and the Freezer Control to B if both sections are too warm.

The 8051AH and 8751BH, while functionally similar, are manufactured using different processes: the 8051AH with an HMOS II process [8] and the 8751BH with a  P422 process [8].  These fabrication differences can influence their thermal properties. ![The table provides thermal resistance information for various electronic parts.](image5)  The thermal resistance, a measure of a component's ability to dissipate heat, is presented as junction-to-ambient (θja) and junction-to-case (θjc).  However, the provided information does not specify the thermal resistance for the 8751BH. It's important to note that thermal impedance values are approximate and can vary based on operating conditions and specific applications [7].

The 8051AH, when packaged in a 40-pin plastic DIP, has a θja of 45°C/W and a θjc of 16°C/W. For a more comprehensive understanding of the thermal characteristics and appropriate heat dissipation techniques, consulting the Intel Packaging Handbook is recommended [7].

The 8751BH, being manufactured differently, may exhibit different thermal resistance values. To determine the exact thermal resistance for the 8751BH, referring to its datasheet or contacting the manufacturer is necessary. 

The provided information does not contain the thermal resistance of 8751BH.

The 8751H microcontroller has specific input and output voltage characteristics, as detailed in the provided data. [1]  For instance, the input low voltage (VIL) is specified as a maximum of 0.8V, while the input high voltage (VIH) is at least 2.0V. [1]  These values represent the thresholds for recognizing logic low and high levels on input pins. 

![The table provides electrical characteristics for various voltage parameters associated with certain microcontroller models (8751H, 8751H-8, 8751BH, 8752BH). It includes input and output voltage specifications, as well as logical input current values.](image1)

On the output side, the 8751H guarantees a low output voltage (VOL) of no more than 0.45V and a high output voltage (VOH) of at least 2.4V under the specified test conditions. [1] These ensure reliable driving capability for interfacing with other circuits. Comparing these with similar models like the 8751BH/8752BH reveals slight variations. The 8751BH/8752BH, for instance, can tolerate a higher input voltage, up to 13.0V. [2]  These differences highlight the importance of adhering to the datasheet specifications for each specific microcontroller variant to ensure proper operation and prevent potential damage. 

The 8751H microcontroller has an input voltage range of 0.8V (VIL) to 2.0V (VIH) and an output voltage range of 0.45V (VOL) to 2.4V (VOH).

To ensure the accuracy of the measurement, place the watch body in the middle of the back of your wrist [5]. The edge of the watch's body should be below the root of the ulnar styloid process, and should not press the root of the ulnar styloid process or be too far away from it. The center of the watch's face should be on your wrist about two fingers width away from the palm [5]. ![The image is an illustration showing a hand and wrist, with a diagram suggesting the placement of a wrist-worn device, such as a smartwatch or fitness tracker.](image3) At a position on your wrist that is about the width of two fingers away from the bottom of your palm, put the end of the ruler that comes with the watch through the buckle on the head [8]. Pull the ruler until it touches your arm, but don't pull it too tightly. Record the position indicated by the arrow [2].  Measure the wrist circumference and select a strap and airbag [4]. To properly measure your wrist circumference for selecting a strap, you should position the watch on your wrist, measure with a ruler, and then select the appropriate strap based on the measurement.

New students arriving at NTU who are offered campus housing should ensure they've provided their arrival details online to facilitate the collection of their room keys [12]. For those seeking accommodation options beyond the campus, the Office of Housing and Auxiliary Services (HAS) manages both on and off-campus housing arrangements [9].  Students can reach out to HAS via email at has-ug@ntu.edu.sg for undergraduate, has-pg@ntu.edu.sg for graduate, or has-exch@ntu.edu.sg for exchange students [6]. Additionally,  the HAS website, www.ntu.edu.sg/has, provides comprehensive information about diverse housing options available to students [9]. For students who plan to stay for more than six months, opening a bank account is advisable [11].
